reviewText:
Having almost completed every accomplishments, I think that giving a review for fresh players should be a good thing to do, lets put features of this game into a summary:

Pros+ Long, funny and shallow storyline, 2 endings for us to choose, 20-30 hours for a walkthrough.
+ Unbeatably cute characters which can instantly make you addicted on this game.
+ Features different types of weapons, items and crafts, making players stonger constantly.
+ Cute CGs.
+ Immersive soundtracks.
+ Reasonable training system.

Cons- The only little flaw is that there are too many items players can miss,mostly important for achievement accomplishments, the only cure is to start a NG+ or to reload a saved checkpoint, and the only way to prevent this is to read achievement guides. Of course, if you do not care about the achievements, it‚Äôs fine, but for those who do care, they have lots of works to do.

I will hereby try to cover as many aspects and features as I possibly can:

This product is also called HDN re birth 1 for short, as a tactical role-playing game, players take control of 3 characters in the front line while keeping 3 others as reserves in the rear. With different combinations players can create their own strategy, when facing challenging foes or bosses this can evidently prove helpful. However, you can defeat the bosses that are powerful more easily if you just train your characters, augmenting several levels. But a strategy is still recommended as it entertains your intelligence, this is also the point of playing games with identic genres.

Now let us see its in-game equipments, including weapons, items and crafts. Weapons here varies a lot, this keeps upgrading your character‚Äôs attack output in general. As to items, the system of HDN re birth 3 also keeps track on your level and gives you different items that you might need in different situations. Healing potions for instance, varies from 1000-10000 points and 30-100% of healing, these potions can be used for high level or low level characters depending on their efficiency, as far as I‚Äôm concerned, this feature is also found in other role-playing games, but since I haven‚Äôt experienced many so far, I still pointed it out. Furthermore, crafts, or plans as named in this game, are very important features, plans are your best friends, they can unlock powerful weapons, useful items in addition to many dungeon maps.

About CGs and Soundtracks, both are well designed, although nothing extraordinary, they do make the players immerse into the game. Especially CGs, they actually did point out the funniest and important events into a more specified way.

Thank you for reading this review up to here, I hope that this helped you a bit, however, if you find anything interesting in any of my explanations or introductions, I suggest you to give this game a try ^^, be aware that you might get addicted very soon ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ ^.^.

reviewText:
Despite what you might think just looking at the screenshots this game actually has less fanservice and anime ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t than you'd expect. Sure there is fanservice scenes spread throughout, but the real core of the content is the parody aspect of the game and the 4th Wall Breaking antics of the cast.

For those of you who don't know, the Hyperdimension Neptunia games are an affectionate parody of the game industry. Much of the humor is based around references that go from the obvious like Mario, to the almost ridiculously obscure like the SNES-CDROM ordeal. That's not to say that is the only source of humor, indeed much of the fun comes from the surprisingly diverse cast with each character having their own little quirks that make them stand out.

As for game mechanics, it is fairly basic turn based system, however there are some notable features that are pretty neat. The order in which each character on the battlefield fights is determined by their stats, once it is their turn the player is allowed to move a certain distance with the character (once again determined by stats, which can be changed via equipment and the usual level ups), and then the character can use a basic attack with a range that is dependent on what weapon their using. The basic attacks are split into three variations, Break, Power, and Rush; each with their own uses in a battle that is best explained in-game. Each character has a variety of skills that are usually just special attacks, healing abilitites, or buff/debuff techniques, these drain the characters SP bar once used. The characters also have access to EXE skills, which are super moves that tend to make fights much easier. The first EXE skill is obtained when a character reaches level 25, and is essential to boss battles. Note though that EXE skills can not be spammed since they use up a bar on the EXE gauge, which has a max of 4 bars and can only be filled by giving or receiving damage.

Also important to point out is that character are seperated into two seperate groups, the CPUs and the Makers. The CPUs are unique in that they have a second form in which their stats are boosted and in general just become all around better in direct combat. While the Makers have a wider variety of skills that are better in the support role, though they are still capable of dealing good amounts of damage. While most people tend to just stick with the CPUs since their HDD modes make fights easier, some battles require the skills from the Makers that the CPUs lack. Combined with the Lily Rank system and the bonuses those grant (for example the heroine's (unlockable) sister Nepgear allows the character she is paired with to deal damage pass the limit of 9999), and you have surprisingly deep party customizing options.

It should also be noted that level grinding is very much needed in this game due to boss difficulty ramping up at certain points. The grind isn't too bad, but it isn't uncommon for the idea of level grinding to turn off a few people.

The PC port is actually quite good considering it was done by a Japanese developer, basic but in no ways unplayable. The framerate is a massive improvement from the PS3 titles, and the graphics actually look like they belong in this generation of games now. Note that in the option menu the resolution states that the max is 1600x900, this is only for Windowed mode and as long as you have the game in fullscreen it should default to your monitor's resolution. If you are having issues you can try going into the program files and editing the .ini configuration file manually to set your resolution (make sure to set the file to Read Only after doing so). There are also some issues with DLC at the time of this review, but the DLC are minor additions and are not necessary to enjoy the game at all (though the addition of characters with an HDD mode like Plutia do make some sections easier).

*EDIT* As of right now the resolution and DLC issues appear to be fixed (at least for me) so the previous section is irrelevant now.

In conclusion, if you are a fan of JRPG's or just a fan of Anime related products then Neptunia Rebirth is a decent addition to your steam library. The upcoming games that will be released have the same forumla with minor changes (biggest being the addition of a fourth party member during battle), but it is worth getting them for the different stories and humor alone; so those are also good purchases if you want your money's worth.

reviewText:
Oh boy, how do I write a review for this game. Let me just say I just finished collecting all the achievements and it took me about 60 hours. I'm normally not an achievement hunter, but I had to do it for this game. Let me explain:

I grew up playing games like FF5-10, Chrono Cross, Legend of Legaia, Suikoden, Legend of Dragoon, Tales, Xenosaga, and etc. Those games were my childhood. Unfortunately, the golden age of JRPGs is long gone, and I do miss it.

Now if those games are like a fine bottle of vintage wine, then this game is like super concentrated Red Bull. Is that a bad thing? Absolutely not. This game is fast paced, linear, and to the point. Dungeons are tiny (and recycled) compared to traditional JRPGs and everything is streamlined, but don't let these things deter you. It works for this game. Sure, the game doesn't have a deep story. It doesn't have heavy character development, and there's no exploration really. But you know what? There's no angsty protagonist whining about his repressed emotions towards a love interest either.

What this game does have is an enjoyable and fast paced battle system (think Tales mixed with Eternal Sonata with a pinch of Star Ocean). The crafting and remake" system reminded me of Disgaea - you can add dungeons and stronger monsters
hoursPlayed: and even raise your credit and exp gain. The 2D artwork is gorgeous and has some animations to accompany the dialogue
voteText: which I found was a nice touch. The game does not take itself seriously and neither should you. It makes fun of gamer culture while breaking the fourth wall on a regular basis. It has loads of sly references to classic JRPGs and games in general. The costume and weapon designs are also nicely detailed. And yes
helpfulPercent: there's a lot of fan service
votesHelpful: and some
votesTotal: I admit
votesFunny: was a bit too much. Some might be turned off by the "loli" aspect of this game
commentsCount: but it's really not that bad.\n\nPlaying this game brought back a lot of memories for me
column16: and maybe nostalgia was the driving force behind my achievement hunting. From the over-the-top finishing moves
column17: to one of the characters humming the Final Fantasy fanfare after battle
column18: the entire game is a "parody love letter" to JRPG fans.\n\nI thoroughly enjoyed this game and I can't wait for the sequel to be ported to Steam later this year. However
column19: for those people looking for a "deeper" and "more enriching" JRPG experince
column20:
I recommend FF7 and 8 currently on Steam.

Some tips that the game doesn't explain and I had to find out "accidently" (based on using an Xbox controller):

1. LB lets you skip any battle animation
column21:
including the basic combo moves. This really sped up the grinding during the later stages.

2. Pressing "X" puts the current dialogue scene in fastforward mode. Press "X" to return to normal speed.

3. Pressing "Y" lets you review the dialogue in case you missed something.

4. Party members in reserve during battle will heal over time
column22:
and thus switching out characters when they are in low health is a viable strategy.

5. Enemies take more damage in the back and the sides.

Now if you'll excuse me
column23: I'm going to return to this game and finish up the Coliseum battles. :)"

reviewText:
At first, I bought this game as a joke because I thought it was gonna be some ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• anime fan service game, but I was so wrong.

This game is insanely fun and entertaining. The gameplay is enjoyable and rewarding. It has a decent plot, with lots of loveable characters. My favorite part was all the hilarious one liners and references to other games. Even though I only have 50 hours on this game (because I'm stupid and saved at the wrong time), there are countless hours of fun. I actually enjoyed it so much, I'm probably gonna get it on my ps vita and play through it again (once I finish the other games of course).

This is no ordinary JRPG. I highly recommend it and it is by far worth the $30 (even though I payed $15).

I have now picked up the second game of the series and am playing through it now. I'm really happy I was able to find this gem of a series in all the other crap that's out there :)

reviewText:
One of the most fun Jrpg's I've played in a long time.

Pro's
-Fun characters
-Engaging battle system
-Music is great
-Story is amusing with all its references / parodies
-Dress up elements
-Theres a Yandere Healer.
-Dual Audio (english / japanese)
-Panty shots of some characters even when your not even trying and they are just standing still.

-Con's
-Cannot be set to 1920x1080p by itself. (NOTE: This is easly changed by setting your desktop resolution to 1080p and selecting Fullscreen option in game)
-Sometimes the characters talk to much in battle, hearing the same quotes over and over (mainly due to when a characters action is done and it moves to your next one the last characters speech is still going.) Can be annoying if you make your actions quickly. Would be better if they had more than 4 quotes for healing / attacking / getting hit.

9/10 Would bang again.

reviewText:
Okay I've played the original PS3 version this game is based off and I can safely say, this game is WAY better than the original. If you had chose between the original and this one, I would say get this one in a heart beat! The battle system is SO worth it when compare to the original.

For those that care not for the original, this game is a visual novel type RPG. Its not your standard RPG, and it does have quite a few funny moments, especially plays on other video games. Not as many plays like the original (Miss the scene where they run into a 'Street Fighter') but honestly, that I can go without, cause the battle system alone is easy to pick up on. Plus you can 'create' new dungeons. If you don't, you'll be stuck with just the story dungeons and you will get your butt handed to you by bosses if you don't try your hand at some of the extra dungeons (I learn this the hard way). But yeah.

The story is a tad different from the original PS3 game, so I say give it a shot. You won't be disappointed (unless this isn't your type of game, then sorry!)

reviewText:
Loli Galore  Best Harem I ever had

Adventure into the world of consoles and fight millions of monsters that all for some reason look almost identical to one another, if not for their color schemes, within a Japanese style RPG with tons of girls.... Actuall there only girls.... We got some male npcs.

I don't really have much to say other than it is a Japanese rpg with an amazing storyline, comical gamer's/weeb's references e.g. the console war, and all well-developed characters. When I played this game myself for the first time, I didn't expect much because I haven't really played something as close to a rpg Japanese game like this. My opinion drastically warped: I was now hooked witht the lights when the girls transformed or when landing remarkable, stunning combos and abilities. What even made it better was the continous jokes upon the modern gaming culture.

But this is just a standard JRPG and if you like JRPGs then this game might be suitable for you.

reviewText:
This game is far more clever than I expected it to be. The humor is sometimes hit or miss, but often a hit, despite the fact that most of my otaku cultural knowledge is second-hand. The basic premise, if you don't know, is that the console war is fought not with business meetings and product sales but with anime girls who draw power from their market share.

Combat is turn-based, but it's the fastest turn-based game I've ever played. Transitions from one turn to the next are completely seamless, the AI takes no time at all to line out moves, your movement is resrtricted to a radius around you rather than distance so there's no cancelling moves over and over to reposition yourself and once locked in combat, your character will attack four or more times with an assortment of thirteen pre-equipped moves you can swap from on the fly, yet you'll soon develop combinations for specific situations that means selecting the given moves is as simple as the press of a button. Fighting something with a full armor bar you want to whittle down? Try AAAA. if its guard is at half so you want to mix up guard breaks and damage? Go for AAYY. Shields down? AXXX. Enemy is too evasive or you need to try for a crit? AYYY. There's no scrolling through long menus to find whatever it is you need. A little slower with a mouse if you want to click things, but not by much.

You can also dress up your gamindustri (the actual name of the world in Hyperdimension Neptunia) lolis with a wide array of costumes, weapon designs and, of course, hats. This is steam. I hear people like hats.

reviewText:
Okay so, after spending nearly 100 hours to get all of the achievements and also be done with the story, here are some of my opinions on the game.
The story is REALLY interesting, it's cute in general. The Characters are super cute too, even some of the ''monsters'' that you have to kill.
The EXP at some point gets hard, but later on it will get easier, after you've done some research. ;w;
The DLC's are OP, Peashy OP at the beginning but then Plutia becomes Really useful later on, for a long time. :P
The only negative thing I can mention is the game crashing at some points, for example when you fast forward the story, the game crashes everytime, but yeah, you just have to know where to stop fast forwarding.

For people that enjoy anime games should get this game for sure.
10/10 would NepuNepu again.

reviewText: Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 is a game that, while flawed in some critical areas, can still manage to win over players with its sheer amount of charm and character, videogame reference-based humor, and a solid set of combat mechanics.\n\nThe story is loosely based on the Console War, with cute anime girls playing the roles of goddesses to landmasses that are based on Sega, Nintendo, Microsoft, and Sony. The idea is neat, but the environments never really truly capture the spirit" of any of the companies being represented and there's a real lack of creativity in bringing these lands alive in that respect. Which brings me to the game's biggest issue: Its lack of variety in locales and recycled dungeon designs. You'll see nearly every type of environment in the first 5 or so hours of the game
hoursPlayed: which will also be the case for most enemies and bosses as well.\n\nCombat is turn-based and fast

reviewText:
TL;DR: This game contains self-aware humor, massive amounts of Japanese otaku culture references, ample fanservice, repetitive gameplay, and general memery. And neps, whatever that means. If this interests you, try it out.

Somewhat Serious Review
As a bit of context, before playing this game I had only heard bad things about the Neptunia series. That its gameplay was bland, its plot was terrible, its characters walking fanservice otaku-bait, etc. I only bought the game because it went on sale and I wanted to see for myself whether these claims were unfounded.

After finishing the game, I had to admit that they were right. All those claims above are indeed true to a point.

Nevertheless, I enjoyed the hell out of this game, way more than any game I had played recently.

This is because, despite its shortcomings, Neptunia has managed to create the most compelling characters I have played in a while, and I say this with complete sincerity. Each character is a caricature of anime tropes but they meshed together so well that I didn't even care. It was fun to see them interact back and forth about inane random Japanese crap while breaking the fourth wall with abundant anime/manga/game references. The plot is very basic, but I found myself continuing to play onward just to see what the characters would do next. The experience is similar to being on an anime ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• forum but without the virulent hatred, if you can relate to that. There isn't really any deep character development, but I still found the characters relatable and likeable, and this had nothing to do with the plot." Hell
date: you could take out all the fanservice and It'd still be great (at least for me.)\n\nThe actual gameplay portion of the game is decidedly lackluster. You will be playing recycled maps with recycled enemies using the same damn move over and over again. Luckily
recommended: the game seems to be aware of this and gives you a good deal of tools to combat the grindy experience. There are in-game mods ("plans") that do things such as weaken the enemy and massively increase the rate your super moves ("ex drive") charges. Furthermore
hoursPlayed: there is a skip-all-combat-animations button
voteText: that is a godsend for grinding exp and drops. Once you start picking up the pace
helpfulPercent: and reliably killing large exp "dangerous" enemies
votesHelpful: the game becomes almost laughably easy. It'll take a while to get there though
votesTotal: so keep in mind that the early chapters are still a fairly large grind. Overall
votesFunny: whether you're going for 100% completion or merely completing the story as fast as possible the game caters to you either way at the expense of combat difficulty.\n\nThe soundtrack is nothing special
commentsCount: and somewhat grates on the ears after a while
column16: but it does fit with the upbeat tone of the game and has an acceptable variety of tracks. The voice acting however is excellent. I only played with Japanese voices
column17: but the voice actors did a very good job of capturing the personalities of the CPUs. The game would not be as enjoyable as it is without the quality of the voice work.\n\nFinally
column18: there's a good deal of fanservice if you're into that.\nIf you're bothered by it
column19:
I will warn that it only gets increasingly prevalent in the sequels.


In conclusion
column20: Neptunia Re;Birth1 is a real love-it or hate-it type of game in a real love-it or hate-it series. There are some glaring gameplay issues and the humor is not for everyone.\n\nNevertheless
column21: against all my better judgement
column22: I really love this game."

reviewText:
It all started with a simple Skype call, talking about cringy games and whatnot, right around the time of the Steam Winter Sale.  A little game called Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 instantly catches my attention,  to which I would share with my comrade about how cringe it was, making all sorts of comments about it. This is when a bet was formed, my comrade had challenged me to a 1v1 on League of Legends, which led up to one hell of a bet. It was simple, the loser was given Neptunia for free from the winner, to which the loser would have to put an active 15 hours into at minimum.  Needless to say, I got ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing destroyed.  I accepted my fate with my remaining dignity and downloaded the game overnight, being mocked and teased all the while. The next night, my time had come. Booted up the game, saw the anime-esc opening sequence and nearly killed myself on the spot, but I dared to tread on, I still had 15 hours to go. During this opening scene, scolling between dialogue of 4 unnamed Goddesses having an argument for god knows what, land or some ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. Then the flat chested whitey called the green one Thundertits, I actually ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing laughed, I was not expecting that at all. At that moment I knew the game had changed, this may not be so bad after all. Got into the actual game, find out it's a turn based RPG-esc game, end up actually enjoying it immensely. I hid this fact from my comrade, ended up hitting the 15 hours in two days. It's been a good month now, 65 hours in, comrade thinks I am weeaboo scum and abandons me.  IT ALL STARTED AS A PRANK BRO, PLEASE SEND HELP.

Pros
You get to stare at animu tiddies for the entirety of the playthrough, zoom feature included. Wink Wink.
Enjoyable cast of Characters.
Decently fair combat and fun combat, can get repetitive with the big bosses at times. (Even worse if your cast of Waifus can't actually kill the boss, so dying and coming back to it is a pain in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.)
There is a Waifu for everyone. Name your preferance, you got it.
Cheap DLC.
Top Nep.

Cons
Noire's voice is like listening to nails on a chalkboard on an amp.
Some bosses have infinite MP, so they can spam their most powerful move almost every turn, while leaving you with a dead healer every time.
Partial grind-fest for those special items and weapons.
Flat Chested women.
Potential loss of friends, respect from remaining friends, and embarassing your entire family tree.

Dave rates 9/10, would Nep Nep again.

reviewText:
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 1 is a JRPG that throws away any serious story for nothing but references and jokes yet still manages to be somewhat enjoyable.

Now the story is as generic as you can get; the main character Neptune is a goddess that fell from the sky, hit her head really hard and has amnesia. Along the way she meets other characters that join her party trying to help her get her memory back, some of these characters are other goddess's that before they met Neptune all hated each other but they learn to get along. There's a bit more to the story than that, but that's basically the gist of it; Neptune literally takes any serious tone and throws it out the window every chance she gets and at first it's funny but eventually it just gets old.

This game is broken up into eight chapters; typically the order of events goes story, look at new items at the shop, view world map events, go to newly revealed dungeon and repeat all of that. What helps to shake this up a bit is when you're in the dungeons you can freely roam around and instead of getting into random battles you see the enemies roaming around just like you are. When you come in contact with an enemy it starts the encounter, but you can also attack them instead of touching them to get the advantage and have your party members start off the fight. When you're in combat you'll notice right away you can freely move around within the specified circular area, this is the combat zone and you're enouraged to keep your party spaced apart because enemies can hit multiple targets but so can you. Though you can move each character around individually the combat is turn based, so once you move you have to attack or skip your turn; there are three types of attacks that all build your .EXE meter (Which is basically your super meter). Each attack type has different properties, rush type attacks generally do little damage but hit a lot of times in one action and they're used to build the .EXE meter, power type attacks do tons of health damage in usually one swing and don't build .EXE meter very well nor do they do a lot of guard damage, and lastly break type attacks are used for destroying your opponents shield and don't do much health damage nor build .EXE meter that well. You'll also unlock special abilities like heals, spells, or buffs that use SP as your characters level up so you can have defined rolls for each party member like healer, damage, support. Aside from healing when you're low on health there really isn't a lot of strategy involved in the combat, build .EXE meter when you don't have any to use super moves at the end of combos, destroy enemy shields with break attacks than spam power attacks to finish the fight. This game also has a ton of plans you can complete and if you go after all of them it'll take a considerable amount of time, they generally add a new piece of equipment or an accessory you can purchase from the shop but some of them change enemy types in a dungeon or give you more experience/credits from fights.

The soundtrack wasn't that bad, I wouldn't say it's anything memorable; but it really fit the game and some of the tracks were quite catchy.

Though it might have an alright soundtrack this game's graphics aren't anything worthy of praise, the character/enemy models look alright but the environments are really uninspired. Each dungeon has a theme" and each of these "themes" has about 3 layouts that don't change and look identical to the others in the same "theme".

I would recommend a purchase to any fan of JRPGs that really enjoy grinding because that's honestly all this game is
date: a massive grind fest from leveling up to farming materials for plans to get stronger items or unlock optional dungeons. If you're not a fan of JRPGs or if you're not into very grind heavy games than I'd say either get this on a very good sale or skip it all together because there honestly isn't an intriguing story to keep you hooked if that's what you're after."

reviewText:
After playing Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 a few hours I can recommend it:

++ challenging turn based combat, with many skills and gear upgrades
++ dungeons can be adjusted, new locations can be unlocked
++ the game doesn't take itself too seriously
++ the female main characters are funny, hilarious & charming and have a great friendship
++ game is full of references that only seasoned gamers will get
++ funny dialogs
++ challenging boss fights
++ entertaining story

- - some grinding
- - respawning
- - some recycled maps
- - playing with keyboard and mouse is a challenge, but can be learned

If you want to play a serious RPG look elsewhere, but if you like challenging fights, hilarious charming characters and lots of humor this could be a game for you!



PS:
Main tips for mouse and keyboard play:

don't play with inverted mouse control
use W A S D to move
use cursor keys to select targets
use 'o' in the main menu to equip your characters, save, load, etc.
always use the mouse for combat actions (-> click on the controller key-symbols)
use left mouse click in dialogs to get the next sentence

reviewText:
The lead character Neptune breaks the 4th wall every other sentence. And she's funny about it.

It has a fun combo system, funny dialog and some enjoyable characters. It is not a serious JRPG. It's a comedy, so keep that in mind.

However it is a low budget game that is very grindy. You will fight the same monsters and play the same dungeons over and over. The way you unlock plans to reshape the gameplay and unlock items is complex and borderline absurd. But that is what keeps you busy in consecutive playthroughs as it is impossible to unlock everything the first 2 times through.

Even at 50+ hours, I still have a lot of stuff to unlock. I'm sure I could spend another 30hours on this game if I didn't have to get back to the chores I neglected while playing this game.

reviewText:
My full review can be found here.[www.the-backlog.net]

Hyperdimension Neptunia ReBirth1 heads back to the very beginning of the series. After falling from Celestia, Neptune meets Compa and eventually IF as she works to find Key Fragments that are spread throughout GameIndustri! Unfortunately though, Neptune has lost her memory and can't recall who she is.

ReBirth1 is a remake of the original Hyperdimension Neptunia, and while the original game was a bit of a mess at times to play through, this is not. That doesn't stop ReBirth1 from being pretty hard. You'll find it quite useful to make use of the new Remake system to add in new dungeons so that you can get a bit of an edge on the bosses.

The PC version features some issues however - the lip syncing is a bit off, the game doesn't like to run (without crashing) without being in compatibility mode, and some lines of text get cut off in their text boxes. This doesn't stop the game from being quite enjoyable from the numerous video game references spread everywhere. It does unfortunately seem like we won't see a fix for this PC issues though. Regardless, it's quite easy for me to give this a recommendation with it having both an enjoyable combat system and enjoyable storyline.

reviewText:
Transforming girls that morph!?

Pros:
+The game is all around good.
+Story is fun. (Nice to see a not so deep RPG.)
+Art style is nice, nothing original but nice.
+Characters are very entertaining.
+Costumes! (Yes this is a pro for me, shut up!)
+Interesting battle system, nothing super original but what it takes from other games is really good.
+The port isn't amazing but it's still better than most ports out there, hell even AAA games aren‚Äôt this decent.
+Option menu is decent for PC.
+Runs in 60FPS. (Or at least tries)
+1080p support. (Not perfect 1080p it‚Äôs upscale)
+Fully rebindable keys/controller with the ability to bind 2 buttons to one function.
+Mouse controls and mouse controlled menus.

Cons:
--The game is short with a lot of filler and grinding. (If you‚Äôre into that it‚Äôs that fine, I was)
--Battle system is good but can get repetitive. (This is just an average thing for RPGs)
--New game plus doesn‚Äôt give your whole party back; you have to get them back through the story again. Not the DLC and unlocks though. (This is really annoying to be honest)
--True ending is a bit of a pain to get without look it up. (Nothing to bad, at least it wasn‚Äôt like Agarest: Generations of War)
--Voicing can get annoying due to very little quotes recorded. (Nothing to serious but when you‚Äôre angry at an optional boss some quotes will make you mad as hell.)
--No graphic settings other then resolution. (Not a big deal)
--Frame drops across the board. (At least for me, nothing below 30FPS though)

Conclusion:
I actually enjoyed this game quite a lot, which is suppressing because I‚Äôve heard and read that the original PS3 version was just terrible. I can honestly say that Idea Factory did a damn good job upon this game plus the port was big surprise, I was ready for another Dark Souls port.

Disclaimer:
I like anime‚Ä¶ so take that as you will.

reviewText:
A cautious recommendation.

As always with games like these, the bad kind of weebs ruin the review section with their fanboyish sheit so heres the stuff you really want to know.

Hows the port?
Its barebones, no graphics options, some key rebinding which is really badly designed. You'll want to use a controller, I use a PS3 controller through motioninjoy and I have no issues with it. You have to select it in the game menu as usual before it works.
The game is NOT 1080p, the resolution goes upto 1600x900 I think, but when you play fullscreen, it upscales it and the game itself looks fine enough. The character sprites in the VN style dialogue sections show a bit of annoying blur, same as the 3D ingame stuff, but nothing too bad. Considering the art style, its tolerable, but not excusable. The devs need to fix this sh*it, its 2015 and we shouldnt be getting ports from the year 2001. (then again the past year has been a bad year for PC gamers, what can I say)
I cant seem to enable DSR either so downscaling the game as far as I know, is not possible. Correct me if Im wrong though.

The game itself is your typical weeb am I kawaii uguu desu-fest with mild fanservice, clunky animations, lots of fourth wall breaking dialogue and fun/cute characters. Just a word of warning if you dont know what you are getting into, but as always. If you DONT know what you are buying, dont ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing buy it you nerd.

If you are a filthy disgusting weeb like I am, you will love it despite its shortcomings. It feels a lot like trinity universe, but the combat and exploration is much much much better. Even uses some same menu sounds.

The devs seem willing to do something about the issues in the game and quickly patched in some of the issues. I would still appreciate a proper 1080p support. Its the bare minimum that a PC game should have. Dont be such lazy hacks.

reviewText:
Well, there is too much to say. I really loved this game, it totally got me.
-the plot is simple and really nice; it won't be the game you will remember for 30 years but it's a lovely way to spend time
-the characters have all kinds of personalities and looks and they're all very nice
-the scenery and the enemies are often reused, sometimes with different colours, but this is not a big problem
-the gameplay is amazing: there is a large range of moves you can choose to use and the styles are great too
-music is also very sweet
So, if you find this game in stock, and you like anime and RPGs, why not buy it?

reviewText:
Hyper Dimension Neptunia Re;birth1 is a turn-based jrpg that quickly immerses you into a Fantasy world ruled by goddesses that are fighting each other for control of Gamingindustri. The story is very funny and the characters break the fourth wall quite often mentioning the player(you) and the video game itself; while even giving references to other franchises like Pokemon.

If you do not care for side quests/objectives and only the story, then the game can be cleared in less than 10hours but if you want the true ending it will take atleast two playthroughs plus nearly all side dungeons. The regular trash mobs should never give you a problem but the bosses can kick you around a decent amount.

At some points you may have to go back and grind some to be able to take some bosses on, if you cannot afford healing items or taking too much damage. The attack animiations are pretty flushed and the cinematics for supers are well done. Most of the time the enemy AI seem to just attack whoever is closest to them and does not use their own abilities frequently enough. And constantly clearing dungeons can get repetitive as there are no puzzles to solve, objects to interact with, etc.

The game offers plenty of playable characters but you may only have 3 on the field and three on the bench at any given time. All characters can be customized by crafting/buying outfits from the stores or getting clothes in chests through dungeons.

In summary, this game can be a breath of fresh air if you've been looking for an rpg with a little twist to it. And you can have lots of fun following the story and watching the cinematic attacks. I'd recommend this game if you are also into tactical-turn based rpg games. In my opinion it is not quite worth 30 dollars though so catch it on sale.

reviewText:
9/10, a good JRPG with good characters and a nice story.

If there was one complaint I have, it'd have to be that there's no autosave system. I once got sent back over 30 minutes of progress when I died during a certain boss fight.

Otherwise there isn't any real flaws I can point out. It is what it promises to be. It re-uses a few level layouts but that isn't really an issue.

The customization was really good too.

If I had to sum it up, Hyperdimension Neptunia is a game about grinding girls who you wish to grind.

reviewText:
Good news for all you Linux gamers out there: It works with wine!

My sorta crazy setup is:
Lubuntu 64bit
wine 1.7
PS3-Controller

You have to start steam in 32 bit wine and using the wine browser navigate to the install directory of Neptunia to start the exe. The game won't work if trying to start it from steam for me.
After configuring the controller key mapping, everything works.

The port seems kinda buggy at the moment. It randomly stops to accept keyboard input (only mouse works, which might get you stuck in the game). Didn't have this using the controller yet. The game also crashes sometimes after battle. Not sure what triggers that, might be the time you spent fighting.

I experience absolutely zero lag, which is awesome considering it's running through wine. Machine specs are:
AMD FX 4300 @ 4,2 GHz
AMD Radeon 6950 (fglrx drivers)
16GB DDR3 1333

I have it on my Vita already, but playing on a large screen at home is so much better compared to a handheld. Don't need mobile gaming at home.
Despite the occasional crash, this game is awesome. Get it. NOW!

reviewText:
First of all. If you do not like any RPG, go out of here.

With the remake of the first Hyperdimension Neptunia it is now possible to enjoy the series without having a Playstation. I am very happy with it.

There is a really solid gameplay. Dungeon-selecting and a TBS-Battle-System with some extras. There are no random encounters. The difficulty of this game is not that hard.

A system makes you able to add different content. For finding the right materials you can add dungeons, equipment, outfits and enemies or even change the strength of them. So you are able to change a part of the game as you wish.

Like most RPG the focus of the game is the well explained story. Well it is true that there is a really nice story
but I must confess the core of this game is the humor. There is a ton of game references, which usually makes you grin.
Character names, quotes, jokes, eveything is there.

The whole story is explained with dialogs like a visual novel. There is much to read, but in the end it is always funny. Between the battles it is always relaxing just to read the dialogs.

Nep-ko should really eat her eggplants, because they are so healthy.. uhm nevermind..

This game is one of the few games I really wanted to have for release. The price was really worth it.
If you like RPG and are interested in the Console War in Game Industri, then you should buy it.

reviewText:
Review For Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth1Review by: DEHU

Pros :- Good graphics
- Funny Dialogs
- Great Story
- Good voice actors
- Fantastic controls

Cons :- too much grinding

Review :Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth1 is a remake of the original Hyperdimension Neptunia for PS3 with better cinematics and new type of gameplay.

Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth1 is about the console wars we know of today. The endless fight between Playstation, Xbox, Nintendo and now Sega.

The nicknames of the 4 goddess are the color of the consoles like, Green heart is Xbox, Black Heart is Playstation, White Heart is Nintendo and Purple Heart is Sega.

You control the goddess Purple Heart or Neptune that suffers from amnesia after a fierce battle between the other goddess that too her out. Neptune meets Compa, that is a reference to company that made this game; Compile Heart. Later in the game you meet IF that is a Reference to the publishers; Idea Factory.
The game is kinda huge, and with lots of dungeon crawling.

You have the ability to create custom moves with Discs and such. Every Goddess have a HDD transformation also called Hard Drive Divinity, that makes them even more powerful.

There are DLC to get 2 other Goddess on your team almost from the start, Peashy(Yellow Heart) and Plutia(Iris Heart).

The game have loads of humor and it's VN style is loveable.
The only sad part is that, it's grind based. So you have to grind up by doing quest to earn Exp and money for new gear.

Additional Infomation :Developer: Idea Factory, Compile Heart, Felistella
Publisher: Compile Heart
Genre: Singleplayer, RPG, Anime, Dungeon Crawler
Released on PS Vita: 26 August 2014
Released on Steam: January 30, 2015

Follow my Curator page :http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6858371/
This review is written for :The Panda's Corner

reviewText:
The weeb in me loves this game. The RPG lover in me is left wanting more. The actual gameplay amounts to, breaking the enemy's guard, and then use your strongest attack until the enemy is dead. If you are not on the same level as the thing you are fighting, you're dead. And you'll need to grind. There are plenty of enemies that give a lot of experience so once you find those enemies you can get a lot of experience quickly.

The actual gameplay of this game is not that fleshed out. You can move around and position your characters before you attack but the game does nothing to make you change where your characters are standing. An enemy MIGHT walk out of range from your party members and you MIGHT have to move them over an inch to attack them again. But there are no enemies that force you to move out of the way of a devastating attack. There are no enviromental hazards that force you to plan your movements during fights. Nothing like that. So being able to move your characters in fights is basically pointless.

There's no real nudity in the game but there is a lot of cleavage and mention of breast sizes so it does well to titlate and make you laugh. But it doesn't do enough to challenge you in fights outside of: Are you high enough level? Ok you win. In conclusion, the fanservice is good, the gameplay is not. That being said. I can't really NOT recommend this game. I didn't get exactly what I wanted out of it. But that's not to say that you won't.

reviewText:
A revamp of the PS3 release. Re;birth 1 removes the bland and tedious of the first game (but still enjoyable) and replaced it with goodies from its mk2 sequel, primarily its semi free-roam battle system, as opposed to the original's FF-sqeue turn-based combat, all while still maintaining its charm and eyecandy fans have come to expect and love. Console jokes and character conversations also include references and jabs at the first game, giving players who played the original PS3 release a good chuckle or two.

Being a Vita port, the game doesn't run on native 1080p, but it's not a deal-breaker. In fact, I find it very well optimized for a port aside from its post-release issues and glitches. Gameplay is fluid and 'breathing' character portraits bring life to its cast during dialogue. Best played with a controller, a KB+M is fine but navigating character movement and camera angles with two sets of movement keys while inputting commands isn't fun.

Highly recommended to anime and VN fans, or anyone who falls into the niche JRPG segment of the market.

reviewText:
So like now that I have over 24 hours in this game, let me talk about it. There aren't many RPG's that keep my attention at all.

Infact it's extremely rare for me to spend even 5 hours playing one. This however I keep coming back to for more. Why? Lets gloss over the pros.

Pros
+ Cute girls
+ Very fun combat system
+ A lot of things to unlock
+ Can customize characters with outfits and accessories
+ Fun system mechanics like the plans and rebuild system.
+ Can get pretty difficult. Is quite a challenge.
+ Developers are awesome people. You have an issue? Guarentee it'll be fixed the next day if you report it.
+ Awesome special moves. So many of them too.
+ Waifus

Cons
- Story isn't all that exciting.
- Only three characters allowed at once in battle. This is just something I dislike.
- Not the longest of games.
- Grinding and grinding and grinding.

All in all? I would recommend this game with confidence. Even if you aren't that great at RPGs.

reviewText:
If you are a fan of the Neptune series, this is a must have. Finding the original PS3 disc is a pain and costs a ton, and even though I have a Vita, Re:Birth 1 is still $40 and I have no more space on my memory card. I absolutely love that we are starting to get some JRPGs on Steam that were formerly console exclusive.

The gameplay is turn based with a field, think Final Fantasy 10 meets Tales of Vesperia. The difficulty rises quickly and as with most JRPGs there is grinding involved in order to stay on top of the difficulty, which is a plus in my book.
There are plenty of customizations available in this game, from attack lists, to outfits and weapons. Plenty of content to keep you entertained for 50+ hours, maybe more if you get the DLC that allows you to level to 300, not sure if there was DLC to let you get to 999 like there is in HDN:Victory.

Obviously as this is day 1 there are some minor issues with the game. It doesn't have 1080p as advertised, it is 900p maximum. Some of the buttons still retain their Vita icons and a few in the tutorial are mislabeled. Controller support is wonderful using an XBOne controller, however the input seems limited to 8 directions rather than true 360 analog support.

All in all it is a wonderful game that finally has made its transition to Steam. Definitely worth the $30, at $15 it is a steal.

reviewText:
I've read there is a PS Vita (or whatever it is called) Version of this,
after i watched the Anime. And since i'm not really a fan of PS
(except for a handful of great games) i didn't bother to look further into it.
Then i've seen it on steam recently and decided to buy.

So, now i'm about to finish my second cycle...
and i regret not a single second or cent i spend on this game.
if i had known it would be THIS entertaining, maybe i would have
even bought that PS handheld just to play this. Oh, OF COURSE
this game isn't flawless, and considering that this is the first port
from a handheld to PC it is still very good.
(On a Sidenote: i don't get any crashes or bugs so far
except this two, which could be caused by other things:
- game freezes on entering fight, if the game session is longer
then 5 hours (going to main menu avoids that)
- after playing League of Legend" this game won't start until
a reboot of the whole system (this might be caused by the other game though)

if you can excuse repeating mob models and dungeon levels (there are still a lot of different ones though)
and if you don't dislike some hours of grinding to get all the stuff you want
date: this game might be for you.\n\nanother nice thing for the grinding is that you don't need to train each character seperately
recommended:
since everyone (including not fighting ones) gets a share of EXP and you can exchange the used formation as much as you like to avoid "stupid grinding" and seeing the same things over and over.

for those who already have it and have problems to farm the stuff you need try this: http://neptunia.wikia.com/wiki/Bestiary/Re;Birth1
it helped me a lot
hoursPlayed:
also there are very helpful guides in steam. i got all characters and most plans and equipment within the first two cycles. now i'm aiming for collosseum and costumes :3

to sum it up:
9/10 - this will be my first 100% cleared game in a long while (and i will buy Re;Birth 2 asap ^^)"

reviewText: This is my first time ever approaching a Hyperdimention Neptunia game and to be honest, I had no idea what I was in for. I thought it would be a OMG LOOK AT THE BOOBS JIGGLE" game. And let me tell you that while some jokes revolve around boobs and fanservice
date: that is not the main focus. Not by a long shot. I also played with a controller exclusively so I have no opinion on keyboard controls\n\nThis is a wonderful JRPG adventure with well written
hoursPlayed: Neptune jokes around quite a bit but knows when to be serious. It feels like an Anime that you play
voteText: in more ways than one. The combat is turn based but the attacks are flashy and pretty sweet to look at. Getting tired of basic attacks? reviewText:
This is a remake of a PS3 JRPG that's also available on Vita. I hear the original was a much worse game, and I really don't dare imagine how that was like. It's a cheap budget JRPG (new price was 15 bucks on launch sale) with emphasize on cheap. There are only like half a dozen dungeon layouts, while there are 50 dungeons in the game. So basically each dungeon is copy pasted 10 times with only the enemies replaced. The dungeons are super short too, you can run from the entrance to the end usually in less than 5 minutes. The storyline is also only presented visual novel style with textboxes and talking heads. Cities are implemented as simple menus. So you either watch dialogues or you pick a dungeon from a list and run through it. Really this game probably cost less to make than the PS3 licensing fees...

Still, it is suprisingly fun. Combat is turn based with a bunch of systems piled on it, and there is a massive crafting component involving hunting monsters for materials and crafting plans to unlock new equipment or dungeons. And the grind is so extremely streamlined, you can breeze even through special bosses within 10 seconds by liberal use of the ultra smooth animation cancel button. There are also absolutely no loading times, everything appears and works instantly. So the grind can downright turn into a rush and feels very satisfying. Think the loot and kill vortex of Diablo, but as a JRPG.

Oh also the story is a parody of the console war in the current game industry. The entire cast of the game is female with permanent fan service forced in your face. The main character is a personified Dreamcast and there are also Playstation, Xbox and the Wii present. Ofc the Xbox has the biggest ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• while the Wii is as flat as a washboard and gets extremely jealous if that's pointed out to her. At the start they are all mortal enemies but of course they eventually band together to fight a greater evil. It is in no way shape or form serious and constantly goofy and 4th wall breaking. I thought I would hate it but honestly, I think I prefer this absolute nonsense over yet another embarassing teenage melodrama or boring as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• Hero Alex gathers the stones of power to save the world from the evil wizard ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• as you'd usually find in JRPGs.

Mild recommendation.

reviewText:
Update: After 51 hours (Excluding hours I left the game running and didn't play,) got all the Achievements for the Game. I enjoyed this game so much that it's literally the only game I actually bothered to do Achievements for. Also the first Game I actually decided to do the Trading Cards for. This is definitely a great casual Game worthy of many playthroughs.

Really surprised with this title so far (14 hours into the Game at the time of this post.)

The Story is quite... Interesting. It is not your typical straightforward story. The Basic plot is that the CPUs are in the middle of a Console War. Yes, a Console War. This is where your Story starts off. If you can comprehend that and the fact that the game has a lot of 4th wall breaking context to some times insult its players and have wacky dialogue, the Story is for the most part Satirical all the way through, which is very interesting, and I actually like it.

One main piece of advice I can offer to any one interested in Re;Birth 1: I recommend one of two things.

1. Watch the Anime. (The Anime is an adaptation of the Game, and takes place some time after the other games. Main reason I list this is because it's a good way to get used to the Characters, and if you can handle the wacky / cheesy dialogue in the Anime, you'll fit right in for the Game.)

2. Grind. Grind. Grind, and buy Item Upgrades / make the Upgrades VIA Plans at every opportunity they become available.

People say that this Game is pretty easy. Maybe if you played it before it came to Steam, that is understandable, but this Game is by no means easy. It is actually VERY hard / some times frustrating.

The Game runs Eight Chapters. If you are not grinding / purchasing upgrades at every opportunity, you will notice how hard this Game can be when you get halfway through the 2nd Chapter. The other problem is that the Bosses have a lot of RNG to them, where they can either do a Normal hit to you, a Powerful hit that might kill you, or an Attack that hits all of your Party Members in close range, even if they aren't even in front of the Boss. Reviving your Party Members when they get downed is also RNG, because from what i've experienced in my own Playthrough, the Boss likes to immediately attack and kill the person you revive almost 90% of the time before it switches to one of your other party members. If you're coming into this game thinking that you'll blow through it without using Healing items or Game Over'ing at all, you're in for a rude awakening.

Get used to how the Dungeons look in the first two chapters of the Game, because you're going to be seeing them all the way until the End. I can't knock them on this because if you can tell already that the Game doesn't take itself seriously and that it mocks a lot of things, especially in the Gaming world, you could see this as them mocking Games that use the same Layouts constantly.

Soundtrack is also pretty decent, but a lot of areas unfortunately use the same background music way too often. Can't knock this either for similar reasons that I listed for Dungeons.

If you can get past all this, this is definitely a very fun game, albeit very challenging as well. Would definitely recommend to any one that likes JRPGs, and I look forward to the rest of the Series coming to Steam.

reviewText:
I bought this game because of all the positive reviews and stupid (in a good way) looking setting.

If the half naked anime girls don't turn you off (or, even better, you like this stlye) you can find a pretty solid game underneath.

The story doesn't win an Oscar but is keeping me engaged. Most of the fun comes from the cute dialogues and references to anything game related anyway. The charakters break the fouth wall quite often and the overall atmosphere is very light-hearted. The game just wants to be fun and make you smile and succeeds.

There are tons of items to find, buy and craft. Add a good variety of abilities, spells, combos, some kind synergies between characters (if they like each other, you get bonuses) and you get great possibilities to customize your party. If you like experimenting, the game might be for you. Getting all the Plans, trying things out can be pretty addictive.

The combat is turn-based on a 2D-Battlefield. Positioning is key, since all attacks have an area of effect. Standing at a wrong place can seriously ruin your day. Attack animations are also pretty good, so cambat is challenging and fun to watch. I strongly recommend a gamepad for the best experience. Playing with keyboard and mouse is possible but doesn't feel great.

I won't comment much on the graphics. Look at Screenshots and videos and decide for yourself. It's a bit outdated but not ugly. Works for me.

However, this game is not without flaws.
The combat can get repetetive after a while, since the game tends to be quite grindy. You often have to get a few levels because of a difficulty spike and the MMO'ish quests (Kill X of these, bring me Y of that) increase this.
The fact that dungeons and enemies are frequently recolored and reused does't make it better either.
Oh, and you have to save often. There is no autosave and when you're dead, it's game over.


To sum it all up: 7/10, fun game with some flaws. Would buy again

reviewText:
First of all, I'd like to give a shoutout and thank a couple of friends of mine from allowing me to enjoy this game. One of them for getting me into this franchise and the other one for gifting me this game when it was on sale. I'm not gonna make any mentions, but they know who they are!
Now, Hyperdimension Neptunia... I remember seeing this game back as a PS3 exclusive, a few years ago. But I didn't feel like playing it and I couldn't buy it cuz I didn't have a PS3 at the time and the one thing to get my attention where the main characters on the cover. So this was my first shot at it.
For starters, the story. And I'll try to talk about it here without spoiling too much, here. The game takes place in Gamindustri, formed by 4 lands (Planeptune, Lastation, Leanbox and Lowee) and each have a goddess who rules over them (Purple Heart, Black Heart, Green Heart and White Heart). Now the story starts with all 4 goddesses battling each other in a land called Celestia, which is above Gamindustri. All 4 with the exact same objective, which is to win and rule over all 4 lands. After battling for a while, Black, Green and White heart consider getting rid of one of them to make the battle easier and join forces to get rid of Purple Heart. They successfully do it, Purple Heart falls off of Celestia, landing on Planeptune and losing her memory. After falling, a girl aspiring to be a nurse called Compa finds her and becomes friends with her, promising to help her getting her memory back.
I find the gameplay good. It's easy to move around when free roaming and I found the controls for combat easy to get comfortable with. Besides, the combat's pretty varied, as each character has a lot of different attacks and special moves. Though playing this game can be a little difficult, depending on your situation. The game does support keyboard, but I highly recommend a controller.
For a game that originally came out in 2011 for the PS3 and was ported to Steam and PSVita in 2014, I don't see much of a difference in graphics. Which doesn't mean it's bad, actually. If the game still lags for you, it's most likely because the game's loading too any enemies and any small details, in the dungeons.
The game's pretty fun and if you pay attention, you can notice a lot of jokes. And also something which is pretty well made in this game, which is 4th wall breaking. A lot of it!
But with all these pros, obviously the game also comes with it's share of cons. And I've experienced some of them. Even though this game is great, you may kinda get a little tired of some of the dungeons you'll see throughout the game, as Idea Factory recycled a lot of dungeon layouts and a lot of enemies, simply renaming them and making them stronger.  Two other examples I can give are that the game suffers from a glitch that can pretty much screw up your whole process if you don't save frequently. Sometimes in combat, the enemies will not move at all, during their turns. They'll just stare at your party without attacking at all. Idk the solution for this and a lot of people complain about the same issue in the Steam forums and so far, no solution to this problem. So if it happens, force close the game through the task manager. The last problem I can mention is that sometimes, the game randomly crashes in between intros. Idk if anyone else has had this issue, but it has happened to me a couple of times. But very rarely. So here's a piece of advice for you who buy the game: save frequently.
This is something I'm gonna start doing, with my reviews. My final verdict for Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth 1 is a 7/10.
This is a great game. And it had potential to reach a higher score! Maybe even an 8/10, imo. But with the few issues it has and with so many recycled content in the game, it kinda drops the score I personally give the game. But still. It's a pretty fun experience and worth the money! I still strongly recommend this game to any JRPG fans and anyone who's looking for a new game to play.

Gameplay: 8.0 / 10
Story: 8.5 / 10
Difficulty: 8.5 / 10
Moe: Neptune / 10

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=- FULL REVIEW BELOW -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 is the first in the Re;Birth series to be featured on the PC platform, and quickly picked up popularity through online sharing and Twitch.tv.  Having spawned a small religion, the game has what some would consider an intense fanbase, and you too shall soon be unable to remove Neptune's adorable face from your memory.

The game follows an amnesiac, Neptune, on her journey to rediscover both herself and her purpose.  Along her journey, she encounters numerous individuals who inevitably join the party to create an adventuring force to be reckoned with.  The characters, in truth, carry this game.  The attention to detail and humour which accompanies each of them is something which makes Re;Birth1 a stand-out amongst many other JRPGS.  As you progress in the story, you are able to visibly see the personalities and relationships of the characters develop, and this in itself is a rewarding element to the game.

The animations and graphics of the game don't quite match Black Desert's, but this is to be expected from a cult JRPG.  The art-style is cute, and the accompanying sound effects to almost every movement you make in-game will have your eyes widening with joy before too much time has passed.  The cutscenes which take up a large portion of the game, around sixty percent, are beautifully scripted and there are very few errors in the English translation should you play with this option toggled.  The voiced dialogue is flawless on all counts in Japanese, and I would recommend having these voices enabled even if you wish to read along in English.

With regards to gameplay, this game is a JRPG.  By that, I mean that you can expect some grinding, and a lot of repetition.  Particularly in Act II, which I personally find to be the toughest Act for new-starters, you'll find that grinding is almost a necessity for progression.  The game rewards grinding, with a tonne of late-game and potentially infinite replay-ability by way of the Colosseum.  The difficulty is hard by default, but you are given the option to make it either easier or harder as you progress in the game.  It should be noted that the grinding possesses certain psychological benefits.

The story (no spoilers here) is compelling, and you will feel an urge to stay in your seat until you've completed it.  The scripts as aforementioned are very well written, and combine the perfect use of traditional anime-style humour and Japanese clich√© storylines.  That being said, there are some curveballs thrown in which you won't see coming- so strap in!

All in all, Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 is a fantastic entry-level JRPG for beginners and some light-hearted fun for those more advanced.  The grinding is, in my personal opinion, enjoyable due to the humour having long-lasting qualities and I don't see myself getting bored anytime soon.  If you struggle with the idea of grinding levels in order to beat a boss, this may not be the best game for you, but I still whole-heartedly urge you to jump into the world of Neptune and her friends!

reviewText:
HyperDimension Neptunia is a series that you will either love or hate. If you are not willing to look past the fanservice and suggestive aspects of it, you will not have a very good time. However, if you are willing to look past those, you will find a series full of well-written and developed characters and a large amount of meta-humour that is hard to not get a laugh out of.

To start things off, Neptunia a JRPG. In the world of Gamindustri, there are four nations: Lastation, Lowee, Leanbox and Planeptune. Each nation is ruled over by a goddess CPU (Console Patron Unit). CPU Black Heart rules Lastation, CPU White Heart rules Lowee, CPU Green Heart rules Leanbox and CPU Purple Heart rules Planeptune. The CPUs reside in Celestia, where they are locked in battle to determine who will obtain the title of True Goddess. After hundreds of years of fighting, a strange voice suggests for Black Heart, White Heart and Green Heart to group together and defeat Purple Heart. They agree and send her careening off the edge of Celestia towards Gamindustri, during which she reverts into Neptune, her human form. After being found and tended to by an aspiring nurse named Compa, it is learned that Neptune has amnesia, and so she, Compa and a member of the Guild named IF set out across Gamindustri to restore Neptune's memories. The story is very lighthearted and rarely takes itself seriously. The characters are all well-developed and likeable, and their conversations often involve the breaking of the fourth wall to hilarious effect.

Gameplay-wise, the game is relatively solid. It uses a turn-based system where you move you characters around the battlefield before using their abilities or using combos. Combos are composed of Rush, Power and Break attacks. Rush attacks are more effective at building your EXE Gauge, which allows the use of EXE Drives. EXE Drives are very powerful attacks that can be performed alone or with other characters, depending on which character is using an EXE Drive. Power attacks deal the most raw damage out of the three, and Break attacks are better at decreasing an enemy's Guard Points. When their Guard Points reach zero, that enemy will take around double damage for a short time.

In addition to the three characters on the battlefield, you can pair them with another three who will provide passive bonuses such as more EXP or increased defences. When two characters are paired together, they have a Lily Rank that shows how much those characters like each other. As the Lily Rank increase, more bonuses become unlocked between those characters. Some characters can even perform EXE Drives together if their Lily Rank is high enough.

In conclusion, HyperDimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 is an excellent game if you are able to forgive/look beyond the sexualized aspects of it. The characters are likeable and believable, the humour is great and hard to not laugh at, and the gameplay is fun and surprisingly deep. I recommend that anyone who just wants to have a good time purchases this game.

reviewText:
You like anime, visual novels, RPG's, and kawaii all over with a cherry on top? Well this might be just the game for you!

I have played this game for about a week now, so I guess it's time to let you know my thoughts on it. This honestly is much more fun that it first appears to be. At first, you may question the gameplay and how the overworld functions - I did a first for a little bit - but once you dig into the gameplay and story, that doesn't seem to be a big problem at all.

For those that don't play that many RPG's, or that have only been familiar with RPG's such as the infamous Final Fantasy franchise, this may seem like a dissapointment, but I can assure you, you will not be dissapointed! I myself, hadn't played a JRPG before, only FFVII, FFVIII and a little of FFXIII, so the battle system and overworld were a little alien to me, but it's not that complicated - it's very easy to get used to after practice. If you are any big fan of anime and as a plus, visual novels too, this pretty much combines both with an RPG. I also like to mention that the character often 'break the forth wall' by poking jokes at some particular RPG mechanics. E.g. A fight narrator (Neptune attacks.....It had no effect....).

Only thing I'll have to say as a negative is that this game does require some grinding in places in order to have a fair fight in places that advance the story. Though after a while, I found some charm in this as there are some monster that you can count as bosses" that can help you level pretty good

CONS:
- Can be VERY grind heavy
- Recycled dungeons
- Repetitive when it comes to unlocking 'Add Enemy' plans

reviewText:
I was skeptical of the positive reviews at first but this game is great. It has that mmo dungeon crawler feel, attacthed to the goofy comedy anime vibe we all know and love. granted ive only played two hours, but so far its been really fun.

One thing i'd like to note is that this game really needs a controller. It is playable on K&M, however i'm finding it to be much less smooth than it would be if i had a controller. Its relatively easy to look past though. The english voice acting is also not consistently used throughout the whole game leading to odd gaps but whatever.

For disclosure sake, i'd like to point out the game was $6 on a steam sale when i purchased it, which may make my review more forgiving than others


All in all, if you have a controller, and want to have some kawaii fun with some fan service thrown in, get it. If you like final fantasy, or fire emblem, you will probbaly enjoy this for the change of pace.

reviewText:
A very cute anime-styled JRPG full of self-referential humor and the occasional handful of fan service.

The game can certainly stand on it's own merits, with an interesting turn-based battle system and a difficulty curve that never feels unfairly hard or boringly easy.

There are also oodles of side-dungeons, item crafting, and quests to keep you busy and entertained until the credits roll and beyond.

If you're looking for a light-hearted JRPG and aren't put off by anime girls and fourth-wall poking (and sometimes demolishing) humor, this is definitely worth picking up.

reviewText:
I bought this game because of all the positive reviews and stupid (in a good way) looking setting.

If the half naked anime girls don't turn you off (or, even better, you like this stlye) you can find a pretty solid game underneath.

The story doesn't win an Oscar but is keeping me engaged. Most of the fun comes from the cute dialogues and references to anything game related anyway. The charakters break the fouth wall quite often and the overall atmosphere is very light-hearted. The game just wants to be fun and make you smile and succeeds.

There are tons of items to find, buy and craft. Add a good variety of abilities, spells, combos, some kind synergies between characters (if they like each other, you get bonuses) and you get great possibilities to customize your party. If you like experimenting, the game might be for you. Getting all the Plans, trying things out can be pretty addictive.

The combat is turn-based on a 2D-Battlefield. Positioning is key, since all attacks have an area of effect. Standing at a wrong place can seriously ruin your day. Attack animations are also pretty good, so cambat is challenging and fun to watch. I strongly recommend a gamepad for the best experience. Playing with keyboard and mouse is possible but doesn't feel great.

I won't comment much on the graphics. Look at Screenshots and videos and decide for yourself. It's a bit outdated but not ugly. Works for me.

However, this game is not without flaws.
The combat can get repetetive after a while, since the game tends to be quite grindy. You often have to get a few levels because of a difficulty spike and the MMO'ish quests (Kill X of these, bring me Y of that) increase this.
The fact that dungeons and enemies are frequently recolored and reused does't make it better either.
Oh, and you have to save often. There is no autosave and when you're dead, it's game over.


To sum it all up: 7/10, fun game with some flaws. Would buy again

reviewText:
Update: After 51 hours (Excluding hours I left the game running and didn't play,) got all the Achievements for the Game. I enjoyed this game so much that it's literally the only game I actually bothered to do Achievements for. Also the first Game I actually decided to do the Trading Cards for. This is definitely a great casual Game worthy of many playthroughs.

Really surprised with this title so far (14 hours into the Game at the time of this post.)

The Story is quite... Interesting. It is not your typical straightforward story. The Basic plot is that the CPUs are in the middle of a Console War. Yes, a Console War. This is where your Story starts off. If you can comprehend that and the fact that the game has a lot of 4th wall breaking context to some times insult its players and have wacky dialogue, the Story is for the most part Satirical all the way through, which is very interesting, and I actually like it.

One main piece of advice I can offer to any one interested in Re;Birth 1: I recommend one of two things.

1. Watch the Anime. (The Anime is an adaptation of the Game, and takes place some time after the other games. Main reason I list this is because it's a good way to get used to the Characters, and if you can handle the wacky / cheesy dialogue in the Anime, you'll fit right in for the Game.)

2. Grind. Grind. Grind, and buy Item Upgrades / make the Upgrades VIA Plans at every opportunity they become available.

People say that this Game is pretty easy. Maybe if you played it before it came to Steam, that is understandable, but this Game is by no means easy. It is actually VERY hard / some times frustrating.

The Game runs Eight Chapters. If you are not grinding / purchasing upgrades at every opportunity, you will notice how hard this Game can be when you get halfway through the 2nd Chapter. The other problem is that the Bosses have a lot of RNG to them, where they can either do a Normal hit to you, a Powerful hit that might kill you, or an Attack that hits all of your Party Members in close range, even if they aren't even in front of the Boss. Reviving your Party Members when they get downed is also RNG, because from what i've experienced in my own Playthrough, the Boss likes to immediately attack and kill the person you revive almost 90% of the time before it switches to one of your other party members. If you're coming into this game thinking that you'll blow through it without using Healing items or Game Over'ing at all, you're in for a rude awakening.

Get used to how the Dungeons look in the first two chapters of the Game, because you're going to be seeing them all the way until the End. I can't knock them on this because if you can tell already that the Game doesn't take itself seriously and that it mocks a lot of things, especially in the Gaming world, you could see this as them mocking Games that use the same Layouts constantly.

Soundtrack is also pretty decent, but a lot of areas unfortunately use the same background music way too often. Can't knock this either for similar reasons that I listed for Dungeons.

If you can get past all this, this is definitely a very fun game, albeit very challenging as well. Would definitely recommend to any one that likes JRPGs, and I look forward to the rest of the Series coming to Steam.

reviewText:
I really liked this game. The thing that killed it for me, hence only 15 hours or whatever played rather than the 70+ the top reviews have, was the massive grind to beat the second boss. Like, i had to grind for a very, very long time to beat that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing boss. It was awful, boring and killed it for me.

The combat in this game was pretty awful at first, but after tinkering around and figuring it out, it became a thing of beauty. After a little testing on your own, you'll be able to figure out which moves to use when and how to hit multiple enemies at once. It begins to feel like a little bit of strategy is needed to actually fight, which is nice.

The sheer amount of content in this game is amazing also. There's so many things to craft and so many characters to level up (and dress up in some cases) that the 80 or so hours of playtime i see most people with is not surprising in the least. However, it can feel a little overwhelming if you're a perfectionist who actually wants to get close to a perfect runthrough.

Another thing that should be mentioned is the tutorials aren't that great. They don't really explain enough, I feel, and you kind of have to figure it out on your own. That was also another killer" for me because I spent probably an hour or two just messing around looking through all the different menus to figure out anything mildly helpful. I still honestly don't understand the point of some things or where to find certain items or how to check if an item is good before i spend hours grinding for monsters to drop the one thing i need...

Anyway
date: most of my problems with the game could probably be easily avoided if you're up for googling and looking for guides before you get in depth. Also
recommended: being prepared for the huge grind needed to beat the second boss is a nice heads up."

reviewText:
Rough to start due to having as much breasts flopping as a porno. But if you can ignore your primal instincts long enough a game full of visually appealing animations, unique combat systems and elements from Persona all in one nice bundle awaits you.

One of the few issue I found was that WAY too many breasts jiggling for no reason (including A cup which makes no sense), I felt dirty playing it. The dialogue contains so many videogame puns that any amount of immersion you build isn't going to stay long. With both of the above together I had to stop playing at least three times in the first 2 hours to contemplate what the hell I just saw/heard.

The story (so far) is in many ways an OS-tan fan's wet dream and in others it‚Äôs a nerd comedy with jokes about videogames and computer hardware. I'm not sure how it is different from the PS3 version or if it‚Äôs a new game entirely but after the 1 hour mark I found myself having a good time.

This is not a game I would play if you are in public or in a place where you wouldn't feel comfortable watching porn in.
