reviewText:
Hyperdimension is an interesting concept but not one that i thought id like, i watched the anime around a month before getting it and well i wasnt impressed, it was ok with a few laughs but didnt seem too great. Anyways i dont remember why but this game somehow got brought at some point and well i ignored it for a while then ran out of stuff to do so i was forced.

Now at first i thought it was like the anime trying to be overcutesy but seriously this is gold.

This game is in all seriousess a love letter to the art that is gaming.

pros:
-The game is long, main campaign takes around 25-30 hours id say, if you want the true ending then that adds a few more hours on and you will want to see it.
-combat system is highly addictive and satisfying, its simple turn based mixed with hack and slash, a perfect mix of both worlds id say, struggle to think of a way they could improve it apart from adding more attacks or skills at high levels.
-The storyline is some of the most hilarious stuff that you could ever come across
-Animations and effects are extremely well done
-Very good port, no drops, no crashes. its capped at 1080p but modding tools are at hand to change that minor flaw
-Voice acting is some of the best, they really go with their various personalities, id go as far to say that its some of the best work ever done. Its in english or japanese, pick your poison.
-Each charecters has their own skill set with 90% unique abilties, mostly the low level stuff is given to multiple charecters but they all have various weapon types so how those attacks come out will vary.
-In depth lore based around consoles(mostly the older generation). Its a good send off to those consoles that have passed.

Cons
-People that havent played it will judge you(this bothers some people)
- dungeons cant complex pretty linear
- graphics dont blow your face off
- Once finishing the game you will 100% of the time wonder what you are going to do with the rest off your life.(unless you have the sequel)


All in all though, i cant recommend this enough, wheather you like anime or old games or funny stuff or lolis or consoles or lore maybe even general jrpgs this game is one of a kind. It gets overlooked a lot due to the fact that the way it presents itself isnt really the best style to go with in all honesty but when you look past it then its certainly in the top tier of games on the market.

side note: use a controller(keyboard is fine but there is hassle)

reviewText:
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 is in many ways not what I expected when I bought the game and  that makes the whole experience way better. I honestly expected a short poorly developed rpg that was funny, but instead I got a well developed long rpg that is also really funny, and clever with references. There are many pros and a few cons to this game so lets get to those.

Pros

-Amazing dialogue and humor was laughing through many parts of the game.
-Battle initiation system is good with advantages and disadvantages.
-Battles require you to actually try to win unlike many games that come out nowadays.
-Superb crafting system with dungeons and items alike. It felt like I was creating the challenge in every area and trying to overcome what I just created and I thought that was fantastic.
-Great voice acting
-Many characters to choose from to spice up the game a bit
-DLC is cheap and worth buying if you plan to play the game through to the end.
-More then one ending is also a nice addon.
-The clothes change your appearence (most games fail to do this.)

There are also a few cons to this game.

Cons

-Camera can get very annoying at times.
-Keyboard controls are annoying.
-Very repetitive dungeon design.
-Too much grinding at the early levels which may turn some people off who don't like this playstyle

Overall for turn based RPG lovers this game is a 8.8/10 and recommended for people who like anime style humor games. For people who arent huge fans of anime turn based games it may also be worth it to try when it's on sale.

reviewText:
Pros+Hyperdimension Neptunia on PC!
+Original Japanese dubbing
+Huge loads of 4th wall breaking
+Great characters
+Really fun
+A lot of humour!
+Color palette
+References, a lot of references
+DLCs which add valuable content

Cons-Sometimes requires grinding
-Bossfights are similiar and the difficulty varies on the enemy healing abilities
-English dubbing is dull compared to Japanese one (but there are people who prefer english dub so its up to you)
-Some items are tricky to get due to them dropping only at specific dungeon on specific chapter
-You get the full experience of the game with all DLCs bought

SummaryI really enjoyed every hour spent playing this game and even though i have already unlocked everything possible i will come back to this game. Re;birth1 made me interest in Hyperdimension Neptunia franchises overall and i became a great fan of the franchise because of it. No regrets. Game is really fun with interesting story and the time to time grinding really does not affect the experience of the game. If there was a game i would like to show to people i hang out with, Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 would be that game. There really is no way to explain why it is so great, you just have to try it yourself.

9/10

reviewText: This game is great. I wasn't expecting this to be as good as it is. The gameplay is good (although, it is a lot easier to play if you have a controller - in fact, it's probably best played with a controller), the characters are funny and the graphics are very fitting for the type of game this is. Although the game is fun, you really need to grind a lot in order to beat the boss fights and stronger enemies which is a downside, but the game offers an item that you can craft to make the enemies weaker, which is good for casual games (like me). I love the combo system, as you can be pretty OP if you know what you're doing, as well as the partner system, which lets you perform special moves if your character's affection (or whatever you want to call it, maybe even the friendship level") is high enough.\n\nThe game is also quite funny. I wasn't expecting the story to be too amazing
hoursPlayed: plus the fact that it's very funny makes it all a whole lot better. All the characters have different personalities and they aren't always just your generic personalities you see in your average slice of life anime.\n\nThe game is very bright and colourful. I was very surprised to see that the game's graphics are as good as they are

reviewText: A very good RPG based in a video game-like universe. There are many references to real things and video games such as Dr Pepper, Vocaloid, Touhou Project, Mario or even Metal Gear Solid. The game also allows you to customize the outfit of each of your characters: you have a large range of outfits and hats for each character (except one or two, maybe). Some of these outfits are inspired from anime, such as Steins;Gate or Senran Kagura.\nHyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 offers a wide range of characters (which are unlocked as you progress) which all have different skills and gear - entirely customizable.\nThis game is fairly long - the DLC's (which are quite inexpensive) can extend the game's length. Though if you aren't willing to buy the DLC's, you can still enjoy the game by going for the achievements (I did!), crafting every item possible or completing every Colosseum challenge and Quests.

reviewText:
Put Star Ocean, Final Fantasy and Phantasy Star Portable together with crazy cute flavouring and you probably have Hyperdimension Neptunia Re:Birth1.

Hyperdimension Neptunia Re:Birth1 is an all-girl casted (spare a few NPCs) turn based RPG that doesn't take itself too seriously, with easy to learn but hard to master combat system. Felistella has taken the best of Hyperdimension Neptunia, Hyperdimension Neptunia mk2 and Hyperdimension Neptunia Victory, ripped apart the first of the three and rebuilt it, bringing us the definitive Hyperdimension Neptunia experience.

The story is presented using 3D animations in the visual novel style, has decent pacing and the humour has quite a few laughs (but some groans, too). You'll move the story along primarily through dungeons and events activated in one of the game's four cities. Dungeons are explored in 3D third person, with treasure to find, resources to harvest and of course, lots of monsters to fight. While exploring a dungeon, monsters are encounted by making contact with them. You can get a pre-emptive attack on these monsters by performing a Symbol Attack, in which you swing your weapon at their hit box in the dungeon to initiate a battle. Should you fail to do so, monsters have a chance to launch a Surprise Attack. Otherwise who gets the first move is determined by the characters' agility stat vs the monsters'. Once defeated, monsters respawn after about a minute for you to fight again if you so desire, though they are easy to avoid should you not as they have relatively short leashes.

One thing to note about the combat is that it has some really steep difficulty spikes. All monsters are not created equal, and while the last fight may have gone smooth as butter, the next one may be tough as nails. Certain monsters can become infected with a virus that will recover all damage they have sustained, and provide healthy boost to their stats. A single viral monster can potentially wipe out your party without either careful planning, or a quick escape! The toughest monsters in each dungeon, fortunately will not actively chase you if you don't want to fight them. Seemingly sure of their superiority and unconcerned with your insignificance, 'Risky Monsters' will ignore your existence unless you actively engage them.

Outside of the combat system, the game has fully fleshed out shops with new weapons and armour regularly added. But besides that, the player has the ability to add items to the store through the Remake system. The Remake system is this game's version of crafting, which, as you'd expect allows you to craft items of all varieties including, but not limited to consumables, weapons, armour and costumes. But you can also use the Remake system to, with the right materials, alter the game's difficulty (easier or harder), manipulate which items drop in which dungeons, or even create new dungeons and quests altogether, should you have obtained the required Plan(s) to do so. Some of the harder side dungeons, which are difficult well beyond that of the story dungeons as well as the DLC Colusseum, can add quite a bit of longevity to a playthrough, and into New Game+.

At its end, as far as JRPG PC ports go, Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 sets the standard. After a little buggy release, the game runs smoothly on PC hardware new and old, supporting a wide variety of resolutions up to 1080p (but not 1200p for my monitor, the dastards!). However, it has a fixed graphics quality setting that looks okay but is about par for the course with what a PS3 or VITA would be capable of. My solitary complaint about the port is that the game does not seem to run in true fullscreen. My screen still goes into sleep mode while the game is running if I have walked away for a few minutes. This might seem like an upside to some, but for me it's a minor annoyance.

8.5/10

reviewText:
Product received for free

I honestly can't see why people like this game so much. I got a lot of good signs from my friends about it before one of them finally decided to buy it.
But why is this game as popular as it is? I mean... I guess the writing is good. It's certainly a good parody, but the gameplay is seriously lacking.
The combat system is nice but there's just... so much grinding. From start to finish you need to do it. And it's not even slightly enjoyable. In games like Chrono Trigger, Dark Souls, or Ys sometimes I just grind for a while and not even realize how strong I get. But games like this one remind you of how tedious it is. Right when you hit a wall where the reccomended level is at least 12 levels above you.
The music and areas are generic, the quests are awful,  the UI is confusing... at least not as much as FF8.
Also this game suffers from eggman syndrome
NO FAIR! YOU HIT ME! YOU HIT ME! NO FAIR! JUMP! JUMP! NO FAIR! YOU HIT ME!"

reviewText:
Hyperdimension Neptunia; reBirth1 is a traditional Japanese role playing game combined with a visual novel. The game caters to a niche audience and makes no effort to accommodate newcomers or uninitiated. The storyline borders on the acceptable limits of both the narrative meta and the digital millennium copyright act. The gameplay is demandingly taxing on the player‚Äôs patience. Furthermore, the presentation is borderline insanity and will ultimately make or break the experience. Hyperdimension Neptunia reBirth1 is a game that only pleases a very narrow audience through a collection of either off-putting or appealing elements.

The game‚Äôs storyline demands an extreme measure of patience from the player and a great deal of tolerance for overused references and clich√©s. Hyperdimension Neptunia reBirth1 is set in Gameindustria; an analogous universe that represents the four sided console war of the seventh generation. Each nation or faction is governed by a goddess, or avatar, that represents the faction‚Äôs home console. The player takes control of Neptune, an amnesiac avatar who represents Sega, who in turn has to travel the world and gather allies and fight enemies in the respective lands referencing Sony, Microsoft and Nintendo.
Each nation is headed by a respective goddess with each their own distinct appearance and personality. The ensemble cast is rounded out by characters representing popular franchises and companies such as Tekken and Monster Hunter. The plot has Neptune search the lands for her purpose in life and reason behind the constant attacks on everyone‚Äôs nations by a mysterious adversary. The majority of the plot is told through scrolling text accompanied with expressive portraits. The sheer extent of time that is spent reading is jarring. A large portion of the narrative is dedicated to characters‚Äô development, usually manifesting in a three-way discussion on the merits of substantial bosoms or the palatability of dairy products. The discussions are rife with references to videogame history, internet memes and porn chich√©s which all add up to a staggering number of times that the player will end up rolling their eyes and sighing in mild annoyance. The overall experience is not helped by the characters instance on breaking the fourth wall and actually berating themselves for talking too much, only to resume the cacophony of clich√©d locution.
In all, the plot wafer thin in depth, richly spread with stale tropes and references.

Gameplay revolves around a battle system and exploration with some novel ideals, but ultimately grows stale and monotonous. When not trapped in an incessant lecture on the benefits of fruits from the nightshade family the game plays like a traditional Japanese role playing game. The player explores dungeons with different enemies and treasures to fulfil quests and craft new items. The crafting system allows the player not only to make new weapons and armour, but also reduce the difficulty to increase the amount of power generated when using attacks or the amount of experience points awarded after a fight.
A general battle will be turn based, with each character being a given a slot in a sequential order governed by the character‚Äôs statistics. The player must the position the character adjacent to the enemy and select from the available attacks. Attacks come in three varieties and are either geared toward the generation of EXE power, dealing raw damage or the deterioration of the enemy‚Äôs defence gauge. When a certain amount of EXE power is earned additional attacks may be used or the special abilities may be unleashed to generally annihilate the enemy in a grandiose and gratuitous manner befitting of a mainstream Japanese cartoon. While the system is fully customisable and offers some level of depth, it quickly degenerates into an automated sequence where EXE building will be followed by guard breaking and ultimately unleashing the aforementioned special attacks to quickly end the fight. However, while there is a system in place with elemental attacks and a physical versus magic attack split, it hardly ever has any effect on the battle‚Äôs procedure; eliminating any all need for proper tactics.
Furthermore, the game‚Äôs difficulty tends to spike to unreasonable levels and demands a degree of mandatory grinding for experience before allowing the player to pass to the next chapter of the story. Naturally, grinding comes into play when using the craft system as it demands items only dropped by certain enemies. These enemies only drop the items by chance, so repetition sets in fast when the same enemy is slain over and over in an attempt to acquire a particular item.
Hyperdimension Neptunia reBirth1 stagnates fast under its almost archaically traditional combat system and barely acceptable random drop mechanics while exploring monotonous and linear dungeons.

The overall presentation is where game finds its initial appeal, however, upon further inspection will be the most prominent factor for playing or dropping the game. While the game is bright and colourful, both in setting and characters, the game is terribly guilty of reusing its assets to a criminal extent. It is not uncommon to find the exact same enemy in the final stage as one you found in the introduction stage. Only the name will make any difference.
The dungeons themselves fall victim to the recycling of assets as well. The game contains exactly one warehouse map, and it is reused five times, each time filled with the same or palette swapped enemies.
The main characters themselves in the meantime suffer from stale animations. Characters seem to float over the ground rather than walking on it. Jumping might as well have been teleportation because it violates roughly eight of the twelve rules of animation. When attacking, there is either a blinding flurry with no weight to it, or a brutal swing that looked cool, but did not do any significant damage.
During the story scenes the characters interact through portraits with various expressions. Particular focus is placed on character‚Äôs chest area. Considering the lack of assets in the aforementioned region on some of the characters in addition to the rather revealing attire, it might not be the best game to have installed on a hard drive if the player‚Äôs country of residence has a legal grey area in regards to the depiction of underage looking characters.
The visuals are accompanied by music and voice acting that breach any and all limits that can be endured by a living soul. The music is catchy and appropriately a blend of techno, rock and chiptune. However, the cuts are extremely short, so the same few notes play ad infinitum until insanity ensues. The voice acting is beyond comprehension. Most characters have voices that are so high pitched they can shatter glass. The fact that most of the delivery consists of screaming and yelling only aggravates the situation. Considering that all the of game‚Äôs text is voiced will quickly lead to the realisation that in addition to a JRPG, this game also contains an audio book where the entire novel is screamed at you. Luckily the game features an English voice track that is considerable more subdued and less obnoxious in addition to not dubbing half the dialog in lieu of some much needed silence.

In all, Hyperdimension Neptunia reBirth1 is a very special game with a number of features that appeal to a very small audience. However, for everyone else, this game suffers from stale gameplay, agonising voice acting, grating music, substandard animation and modelling, a bizarre story and dubious character development. Yet, if all of the aforementioned complaints are exactly the elements you are looking for in a game, then I would recommend it. Anyone else will want to take note of it, and rather look for a more conventional game.

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game, However I've had multiple issues with crashes and losing my game saves.

I figured out that when you recieve the DLC characters it can cause a save corruption. the way around this is to get one of the characters from the event after the first boss, and then save. repeat the same steps with the second character. If you get them both at the same time for some reason it causes the game to crash the next time you try to save.
dont lose 3 hours of game time like i did.

also when i updated my pc I lost all of my 6 hours of progress. So effectively I have to start over. I have not found a fix for this yet unfortunately. But I will try to figure it out soon.

Overall this game is great, and you should definitely give it a try. just be careful to backup your game saves.

reviewText:
Welcome to over the top anime wacky nonsense. The game is a massive parody with wacky jokes, parody-pervy stuff and refrences to other things. I don't really like the whole young girl to woman pervy stuff but I'd like to think they did it again as a parody and knew full well what they were doing.

The gameplay is fun and has a fairly deep battle mechanic from building combos, weapon arc differences, transformations, and seperate equipment slots for both character and transformed character...along with some crafting it sounds deep but it's honestly eased in a way that you can get your mind around it.

There's been some mention of technical issues, I haven't seen any of this honestly, I'll leave my specs below so you can go off that. A fix I heard is you run the game in compatibility mode and that sorts the problem if you are having them. Check the community hub where they discuss it. While I know they made an improvement in framerate from 30~ on the Vita to 60 on PC, the lack of 1080+ resolution is confusing. Maybe it breaks something that they haven't sorted out yet? But it's not a huge deal. It looks fine so far, I hope they add more options but it's not subtracting

Intel i7 4770k
8gb ram
gtx 970
Windows8.1

Visually the game is all over the place, character models look great, the maps look PS2 era in both texture and model quality, early PS2 mind you. Cutscenes have animated avatars via emofuri which adds some nice flow/movement ...boob jiggle to cutscenes. They look great and it's odd how much depth it adds to what's going on. They're not fully animated, so don't expect characters to twirl and slash weapons in dialoge cutscenes but it's a nice feature.

Everything is a wink and a joke, enemy characters can just be silly or be cat-PS4's called Purr4. So if you're looking for a complex story that isn't 4th wall breaking self parody that mostly revolves around friendship and cute girls or girls with giant ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•? This isn't the game for you. But if you're okay with that or just feel like trying something new? ...Or got the game for a friend whom declined it like myself...It's worth a shot, good comedy rpg honestly...just turn the game to japanese, then lower the voice volume, Neptune can be quite ...lively.

Edit*******
They've since updated the game fixing numerous bugs and letting the game run at 1080p. Yay for the people porting this game making it even better.
That said I'd love it if they'd fix some of the text that runs out of the text boxes. |:

DLC note:
The DLC that you buy you can turn off in game, as you can get characters from it that aren't acknowledged but help you greatly in game. How much do they help? Well if you choose to use them, you'll find in some story battles they don't let you transform- this rule does not effect the DLC characters and you can bypass this, helping the battle be easier. That said you can also choose to not change them as well.

reviewText:
Now, I'm not sure what exactly compelled me to buy this game. Maybe the kawaii AF animoo grils. Maybe the fact that it had a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• plot. Maybe the tons of hentai doujinshis I would have a more enjoyable time reading after knowing the situation a bit more. But lets be honest here, anime bewbs. The only reason I bought it, and probably the only reason you bought it.
Being a weeb seems to have its payoffs though. This game is actually genuinely enjoyable. A cute little story with a simple yet creative battle system, neatly wrapped up in a nice cell-shaded art style. And also anime bewbs.
The downside though, is probably the whole badly ported thing. The controls are clumsy, and I would've had an easier time translating the bible into Japanese with my left nut than figuring out how to run the damn thing without it crashing after the logos.
So, is it worh buying? If you are an embarassment to your parents, hate yourself and feel you can't go any lower in the pit of No GF and self-loathing you currently inhabit, then go for it. If you want to play the game not for the anime bewbs, then wait for a sale.
8/10 its aight -IGN

reviewText:
Definitelly an amazing game. Took me hours to complete it, but I loved every bit of it. It's half a rpg and half a visual novel. It kinda lacks in viarity in creature and section designs, but definitelly doesn't lack in character hat and dress types. And boobs. Cannot forget the boobs.
The game is funny and has funny characters all around. And it even makes fun of the average tropes and cliches of JRPGs, which I find very amusing. There's sexual innuendos as well, but they are rather lighthearted ones. Which I didn't mind later on into the game. The story is kinda lacking in my opinion, though. There could be so much more.
Gameplay is fun. It's turn based where you can move around in a area, but it has very little strategy. You just try and smash the enemy as much and as quickly as you can until it drops dead. To add more, there are various sections which can be used to power level really fast. So the story quests should go rather easy if you find out the mosnters that give pleanty of exp and are rather easy to kill with HDD'd ladies (spoiler: yeah, the universe revolves all around technology, specifically computer and computer games. So there's a lot of 4th wall breaking). If you bought all of the dlc, getting to level 999 is quite a trip. Even then though, you can just power level in a few hours of hardcore grinding.
Honestly, the game is mostly all story, character design and hats, hats and more hats for ladies and their HDD's. Gameplay is fun if you like turn based, brainless smashing and big numbers, lots of grinding, and badges/collectables. I'm not complaining, as I kinda like that. But you should think twice if you dislike any of these things I mentioned, because the game's quite expensive. I'd suggest buying it at a discount unless you are a hardcore fan of the series or you imagine yourself loving the game/series.

reviewText:
If you know what Neptunia is you don't need to read much of this

Contrary to other recommendations here
There are no realtime physics in this game despite what you might expect


Content could be longer; story is shorter than I expected.
Combat is a novel mix, reminds me of both turn-based like FF-X and strategic-realtime action like FF-XIII
Graphics could have been enhanced more - it still looks like it came off the PS Vita (which it did.)
Music is a mixed bag. There are some individually nice tracks, some ear-worms, but as a whole the problem is a lack of coherency. It's mostly digitalized in nature as expected of the theme, but ... it just doesn't come together, especially if you go through the Audio Museum all at once. On another note some of the tracks have some really peculiar names.

References: nep-nep/nowa-nowa

reviewText:
BOING BOING BOING.. come on, JUST PAUSE and look at all that Dogoo bouncing!(that blue ball of slime lovingness) On a serious note,
Anime fans or pervs around the world, this is the cherry to your cake or make that the game which will take away your cherry... For a game ported from the handheld consoles to the pc, it is already holding up well to the control mechanics(still clumsy around the controls but you will get it sooner, or perhaps 10 years down the road when you're still playing this game)
Story? well you're going about getting a whole crew of waifus to defeat a villain while going through dungeons after dungeons in order to get more materials.. kinda your typical RPG game, BUT with the option of being able to take any chracter and dressing them up for battle.. and being so god darn cute.. ITS A WINNER IN MY BOOKS!!!!:P
This game gets some serious rev in its difficulty past chapter 2-3 which just means more grinding, initially you may think this game is just a waste of time pressing and it should just recieve them pictures of Dogoos but you're hella wrong, gamers can't live without a little challenge now can they?!(unless you're a bondfide pervert and kudos to you...)

reviewText:
Excellent port of quite possibly the best JRPG series going for an amazing comical adventure. Graphical improvements for Battle and Dungeon mode. Hell to the yes. 60 FPS Nep Nep yo. SIXTY. FPS. NEPPU. NEPPU. CAN YOU FEEL IT? CAN YOU FEEL THE AWESOME?! Neptune can, albeit maybe too much. Also Noire is my waifu.

OH, and the fact you now get to enjoy the awesome soundtrack of Neptunia on a system that probably has (I say probably, as I power my system with a USB DAC and a mixer) a much more powerful audio amplification system is just Neppu-tastic. I could sit on the menu screen forever if I wanted... even.. though.. I have the OST... yeah..

The only downsides of this port are hardly a downside at all.

1: keyboard and mouse controls - Just don't do it. get a PS3 Controller or whatever gamepad and use it. There's no reason not to. If you subject yourself to torture via Cursor Confinement-less game window and the awkward controller map scheme for the Keyboard, then  you're on your own.

2: Upscaled Visual Novel models and Aliased Cutscenes - These're hardly worth mention because;
a) The cutscenes don't last long and the models aren't sitting around long enough for you to focus on the aliasing
b) The upscaled visual novel models' quality degredation is hardly noticable as it's just a little bit of blurr. Unless you have extreme autism, you're going to be fine.

reviewText:
Welcome to over the top anime wacky nonsense. The game is a massive parody with wacky jokes, parody-pervy stuff and refrences to other things. I don't really like the whole young girl to woman pervy stuff but I'd like to think they did it again as a parody and knew full well what they were doing.

The gameplay is fun and has a fairly deep battle mechanic from building combos, weapon arc differences, transformations, and seperate equipment slots for both character and transformed character...along with some crafting it sounds deep but it's honestly eased in a way that you can get your mind around it.

There's been some mention of technical issues, I haven't seen any of this honestly, I'll leave my specs below so you can go off that. A fix I heard is you run the game in compatibility mode and that sorts the problem if you are having them. Check the community hub where they discuss it. While I know they made an improvement in framerate from 30~ on the Vita to 60 on PC, the lack of 1080+ resolution is confusing. Maybe it breaks something that they haven't sorted out yet? But it's not a huge deal. It looks fine so far, I hope they add more options but it's not subtracting

Intel i7 4770k
8gb ram
gtx 970
Windows8.1

Visually the game is all over the place, character models look great, the maps look PS2 era in both texture and model quality, early PS2 mind you. Cutscenes have animated avatars via emofuri which adds some nice flow/movement ...boob jiggle to cutscenes. They look great and it's odd how much depth it adds to what's going on. They're not fully animated, so don't expect characters to twirl and slash weapons in dialoge cutscenes but it's a nice feature.

Everything is a wink and a joke, enemy characters can just be silly or be cat-PS4's called Purr4. So if you're looking for a complex story that isn't 4th wall breaking self parody that mostly revolves around friendship and cute girls or girls with giant ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•? This isn't the game for you. But if you're okay with that or just feel like trying something new? ...Or got the game for a friend whom declined it like myself...It's worth a shot, good comedy rpg honestly...just turn the game to japanese, then lower the voice volume, Neptune can be quite ...lively.

Edit*******
They've since updated the game fixing numerous bugs and letting the game run at 1080p. Yay for the people porting this game making it even better.
That said I'd love it if they'd fix some of the text that runs out of the text boxes. |:

DLC note:
The DLC that you buy you can turn off in game, as you can get characters from it that aren't acknowledged but help you greatly in game. How much do they help? Well if you choose to use them, you'll find in some story battles they don't let you transform- this rule does not effect the DLC characters and you can bypass this, helping the battle be easier. That said you can also choose to not change them as well.

reviewText: So, after almost 21 hours, I can safely say: Yes, fun has been had so far. Completely new to the Hyperdimension Neptunia games, it is quite enjoyable. However, it is a port. Without a controller, the controls definately take getting used to, and rebinding helps a great deal. I personally switched right bumper to E, and changed the Y button to J. That solved most of my issues, control-wise.\nThe game content itself is enjoyable, adorable, and contains moe breast fanservice. The characters are adorable. Although, I will say I went directly to the DLC from the very beginning, because I got the game nearly immediately. Had a few issues with glitches early on, but glitches were quickly taken care of. And as far as that goes, as a first look, it's been enjoyed.

reviewText:
I originally tried Neptunia mk2 on the PS3, and wasn't that crazy about it. In addition to the wildly fluctuating fps, the battle system didn't really click with me, and I wasn't interested in the story enough to continue.

I have to say though, this remake of the first game that apparently takes from Victory's battle system has just the tweaks it needed to be really enjoyable. Plus, being able to play the game in 60fps is beautiful, and the port in general while rocky at the start, is great compared to the track record of others.

Beautiful artstyle, self-aware jokes, flashy attacks, fanservice, and enough grinding to satisfy that Disgaea itch, is a recipe for a relaxing experience.

reviewText:
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth 1 follows the story of the land known as Gamindustri, the 4 Goddeses, who rule the lands of Lastation, Leanbox, Planeptune and Lowee, are battling for conquest of the other three, until 3 of the goddesses decide to team up on our main heroine, Purple Heart, or as she's more commonly known as, Neptune.

This game is a 4th wall breaking machine, chances are whatever comes out of the characters' mouths, it's either a joke that breaks the 4th wall, or a joke at anime tropes like tsunderes

Overall, the plot if great, funny, and no way serious in the slightest, it's a video game about 4 goddesses who are basically just Sony, Microsoft, Sega and Nintendo, so adding a serious tone would completly ruin the 4th wall breaking jokes

reviewText:
I can't stand turn based games. I get bored of them very easily. However the combat system in this game was engaging enough to finish the game. I was addicted to this game for a while. The strategy is engaging enough, the moves are well done, and it has lots of cute girls.

YOU CAN SKIP COMBAT SEQUENCES if you get tired of them.

reviewText:
So, It's about time I review this game.
Honestly, when I saw this on sale, I thought to myself that the game will be something like Final Fantasy with lots of menus, tedious gameplay, walking through dungeons fighting on turn-based system with some anime all over it. As it turns out, Neptunia is exactly that, except for the game is actually WAY MORE fun than any other JRPG here on Steam. Warning: the game is self-aware and makes joke after joke about gaming industry, nerds and themselves. Fourth wall will be broken many times, and trust me, it's a good thing.
Graphics are nice and colorful, though, I would like a little more detail in them and much more polygons, since the game looks like something just barely better than PS2/XBOX were capable of. Music is kinda just there, nothing really amazing, but worth listen to and doesn't get annoying.
Gameplay is not for everyone and by that I mean it's only for people who like hundreds of menus in their game instead of combat system, leveling-up, beating bosses and managing parties.
Also, if you like anime, you're in for a treat.
Be sure to buy every DLC for this game, since they're cheap and add new content.

Nep/Nep, would Nep again.

reviewText:
Full of humor and satire, this game made me laugh time and time again. The animebullsh*t here is just the right way over the top and all kinds of reperences to either games, gaming culture or japanese weirdness are droppes frequently.  Do not judge this game by its cover. The writing is excellent and the English translation is well localised. (I played with Japanese audio and English text so I was able to compare.)

True to its theme the game includes a myriad of clothing choices for the heroines - some fairly fanservise-y type :P However, even the most perverted clothing doesn't really have any better stats than the others, so the player is free to choose what clothing pleases their eye the most. I myself felt a bit disturbed by some of the swimwear stuff tbh x'D

If you are like me an obsess about getting all the achievements and unlocking all the stuff, the game will turn a bit grindy after a second playthrough (new game plus). It took me around 100h to unlock everything, but only 30h or so to complete the storyline once. (And I am a slow player who even grinds before advancing the story after any boss^^)

reviewText:
HOLY ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• IT CAME OUT ON PC.

This is easily one of my favorite JRPG games. I've beat this game to completion on the Vita, and am currently 100%ing it on PC.

PROS:
NEP NEP IS ON PC WOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO
Pretty casual battle elements
Solid, and enjoyable story
Decent amount of replayability

CONS:
It's a pretty iffy (heh) console port, so crashes can and will happen
Codec packs can screw with the ingame cutscenes
A battle early on has a pretty solid chance of crashing it
Grinding is sometimes the only way to progress through a certain part if you weren't murdering every living thing on the map

It's a pretty casual game, the battles themselves are nothing incredibly difficult, except for a few early game fights (A fair amount of grinding is required to beat these early on). If you're having trouble, you can always activate a 'plan' (gameplay modifiers and the way that you unlock weapons/costumes/consumables) that makes the enemies easier to defeat. Somewhere around an 8.5/10 for gameplay.

The story is freakin great. The characters are pretty well written (NOIRE IS BEST), most of the dialog is spattered with references to other games and the fourth wall is nigh-inexistant. Overall an 9/10 for story and characters.

Replayability is pretty solid. A single run of the game, if you listen to all the dialog, is easily about 15 hours. There's 2 ending-related achievements so if you're looking to get both endings, it's about 20-25 hours. If you're looking to get all the achievements (DAMN THAT MILLIONARE ACHIEVEMENT) you're looking at a solid 40-50 hours. Plus you can unlock the candidates, which are the main CPU's little sisters (UNI IS BEST). Something around a 7.5/10 for replayability.

Overall, this game is a solid 9/10 if you're into cute moe vidya-gaem console grills.

reviewText:
Its a very japanese cute anime moe RPG. You know, anime chicks with chirpy voices and jiggling ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• in tiny elaborate costumes wielding huge weaponry (giant syringe FTW). Full English and Japanese voice, subtitles and decent although most is not really animated art. The animated art battles are cool, if you like seeing scantily clad chicks do the traditional jump up in the air summon weaponry and fight anime battles. It feels very JRPG consoley. Run around on a giant map, hit enemies or they hit you and a battle starts. Battles are turn based with the ability to run around and choose attacks, and the plot is incomprehesible about some game-land where there are 4 goddesses, one of which gets ganged up on and booted out down to the land where the mortals are, where she is rescued by another jiggly chirpy girl. But youre not here for the plot.

If you're an otaku fanboy looking for your waifu, or you're a weeaboo, you'll love this game. I'm not so sure on my end, cuz I'm not really into the whole scantily clad anime female fighting other scantily clad females as the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• jiggle away.

But for what it is, and for people that are into it, its good. So I'm not rating it down, with the caveat it is VERY japanese and VERY anime moe RPG. If youre into that, you could do way worse than get this game. If youre not, the chirpy voices and fanservice will annoy you quickly.

reviewText:
First off, I'd like to say that I watched the HDN anime first without even knowing what it was about. Eventually, I found out that its origins were from a game (a terrible one). I was a bit skeptical at first when I bought it, but it was 50% off so why not?

Based on the many reviews I've read about the original game, I'm glad that I bought this one. The Remake System that is included in the HDN Re;Birth 1 has done wonders for the game and allowed for drastic improvements to be made overall.

I don't want to get into any spoilers, but I will say that this is one of the best JRPG I've laid my hands on.

The artwork, plot, characters, music. EVERYTHING JUST FITS PERFECTLY.

Maybe it's just me, but the BGM during boss fights and EXE drives gives me tingles every time I get into a battle.  The light-hearted personality of Neptune just makes everything 9999% better.

I've only just recently hit lvl 999 with Neptune alone and I'm planning on doing the rest.
This game is awesome. I haven't even slept yet and I don't even regret it.

Nep-Nep 2 sugoi

reviewText:
.......this was bloooooody ammmmmazing. I had a blast playing this gem right here. The storyline was compelling and the characters absolutely adorable and at the same time...BADASS. So let;s go more in depth shall we..
My likes:
1. The storyline and generally the whole concept of cpus, hdd drive, cds, cassettes...the whole works. Absolutely compelling, plus some instances in the game is absolutely funny.
2. Characters as mentioned before are well put together, unique and we haave quite a lot of anime themes coming in, tsundere, yandere, the whole works....cough cough, might see likkle yuri too.
3. Battle system was also a charm, I must admit though the default controls were shiite.....had to change them to suit my purpose.
4. Requires at least 40 hrs to complete main storyline and sidequests will require much more...

Dislikes.
1. As mention before, default pc contolllers....no just no.
2. I know the thing seh 'risky and hard' monsters but..... have likkle chill compile heart company studio..
3. This true ending thing, listen I got the true ending by complete chance...but seh mi never get it...why not give some hints on how to or what I did. This has happen to me with the first two agarest games that is also with this company..... should i push the redbutton or not-_-


Overall, as mentioned I enjjoooyed this. So if you have interest in jrpgs this is for you. Have fun.

P.S Btw...........I purchased Rebirth 2 annnd I dont know how the hootsfloots I cannt run it although I play this one with u know issues, but it was playable. I really just wissshed that companies port their games properly. If it aint broke....NUH FIX IT-_____-

reviewText:
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1
is a (slightly-grindy) JRPG developed by Idea Factory and the remake of Hyperdimension Neptunia released for PS3.

The four CPUs of Gamindustri are in a bitter fight for the title of the True Goddess". This battle however has been fought for several hundred years already. When a mysterious voice appears to three of the CPUs
date: they team up to defeat the remaining one - Purple Heart
recommended: Neptune - and knock her down to the main land...\n\nIf you have already played other main-series titles of this game
hoursPlayed: the gameplay is pretty much the same as always.\nFor those who don't know
voteText: there is a generic overworld from which you access the dungeons
helpfulPercent: shops and other instances
votesHelpful: the dungeons themselves where you can walk around
votesTotal: collect items and fight monsters.\nEncounters are - rather than being random - based on "symbols" which are enemies on the dungeon map.\nFor combat you can set 3 characters to fight at the same time. During each character's turn
votesFunny: they may move and choose an action (attack
commentsCount: item
column16: etc.). The CPUs still retain their transformed state
column17: HDD
column18: which increases their stats.\n\nAnd then there's even more stuff you can do
column19: but that's nothing worth noting here (and nothing that would change your mind).\n\nThe grinding isn't as bad as many people make it out to be; a little tactic can help you out. And there's fan-service. Nothing all too significant
column20: but it's definitely there.\n\nDo give it a shot if you have no idea what this is
column21: if you know and like the series or you're just bored.\nDon't if hate the series or Anime in general."

reviewText:
Put it on your catch-it-on-sale" list.

Pros

- 1080p 60 fps
hoursPlayed: borderless windowed support (1080p upscaled to 1440p in my case)
voteText: and none of the usual console port problems.\n- Skill system felt enjoyable to mess around with
helpfulPercent: and there weren't many skills that just felt so good or broken that they were the only viable strategies for certain portions of the game.\n- Hilarious dialogue
votesHelpful: lots of gaming culture references
votesTotal: superfluous amounts of satire/puns. With terms like HDD/CPU
votesFunny: names of the cities (Leanbox/Lastation/Lowee aka XboX/PlayStation/Wii)
commentsCount: numerous characters/dialogue a character who's entire existence is to contain references to Steins;Gate
column16: and incessant 4th wall breaks
column17:
I was endlessly amused at the writing.


Cons

- Very unimaginative dungeons. They are not randomly generated and some of the later ones are literally copy-pasted with some different mixes of enemies. There is literally zero puzzle solving and the exploration might as well not exist. It's also impossible to know the leveling of the zones/dungeons aside from just kind of "remembering" the recent ones to gauge the leveling potential.
- The menu is a huge pain to navigate. Items aren't sorted alphabetically or aren't in many logical orders. You can't do something as simple as buy a weapon and equip it on the same screen
column18: etc. Most of the out of dungeon UI navigation is very cumbersome.\n- Have to be sure that my controller is on when I start the game\n- The game consistently crashes when I start it up if it isn't the first thing that I open on Steam. This might have something to do with the fact that I consistently play with a controller? Anyway

reviewText:
A lot has been written on this game already but here are my two cents :

- Yes this game is grind-heavy but i really didnt mind at all. That's thanks to the remake system which provided tons of milestones : i never grinded only for XP i made plan after plan and i leveled up along the way. Also you can skip all animations which makes the whole thing much faster and less tedious.

- There are a few absurb spikes in difficulty at the beginning of the game. It gets better though so dont give up.

- As far as RPGs goes this is more of the sitcom kind. Dont expect a deep story it's about characters you like (hopefully) having fun and being silly. With a ton of references to games.

- You can play with a keyboard just fine but you'll have to remap pretty much every single key. Also the game will still display the originals buttons so you'll have to remember what is what. Took me some getting used to and a few trips to the config section.

- There is a moderate amount of fan service (panties, cleavage, jiggling boobs). You can upgrade" to softcore hentai with mods if you're into it.

- The music is okay. Nothing i wanted to listen outside the game but nothing that made me want to turn the sound off either.

- This game recycle dungeons environnements and monsters models. A lot.

- The achievements are all fairly easy but will take some time. The "millionaire" one is particularly grind heavy
date: even more so if you dont have the DLCs (to raise the level limit and get access to more powerful ennemies)."

reviewText:
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1
is a (slightly-grindy) JRPG developed by Idea Factory and the remake of Hyperdimension Neptunia released for PS3.

The four CPUs of Gamindustri are in a bitter fight for the title of the True Goddess". This battle however has been fought for several hundred years already. When a mysterious voice appears to three of the CPUs
date: they team up to defeat the remaining one - Purple Heart
recommended: Neptune - and knock her down to the main land...\n\nIf you have already played other main-series titles of this game
hoursPlayed: the gameplay is pretty much the same as always.\nFor those who don't know
voteText: there is a generic overworld from which you access the dungeons
helpfulPercent: shops and other instances
votesHelpful: the dungeons themselves where you can walk around
votesTotal: collect items and fight monsters.\nEncounters are - rather than being random - based on "symbols" which are enemies on the dungeon map.\nFor combat you can set 3 characters to fight at the same time. During each character's turn
votesFunny: they may move and choose an action (attack
commentsCount: item
column16: etc.). The CPUs still retain their transformed state
column17: HDD
column18: which increases their stats.\n\nAnd then there's even more stuff you can do
column19: but that's nothing worth noting here (and nothing that would change your mind).\n\nThe grinding isn't as bad as many people make it out to be; a little tactic can help you out. And there's fan-service. Nothing all too significant
column20: but it's definitely there.\n\nDo give it a shot if you have no idea what this is

reviewText: A mere two hours into the game and it's already miles better than I'd expected it to be. Having played Hyperdimension Neptunia from its very first installment up to Hyperdimension Neptunia Victory on the PS3, I can say that having this game on PC is definitely a better experience even if just for the 60 FPS improvement alone.\n\nI'd never played anything from the Re;Birth" line and I've been pleasantly surprised by how much of an improvement this remake of the first game is. It's not a simple remaster at all
date: it's literally a remake.\n\nTasteful dialogue has been added to this game alongside the battle system from the later installments in the series
recommended: which makes it a genuinely fun game to go through instead of a headache-inducing experience. Speaking of headaches
hoursPlayed: if anyone here has played the first game on the PS3 then you'd know how much of a pain some of the soundtrack was to listen to. Even the soundtrack in this game has been composed completely differently and the pieces are pretty fun to listen to. High energy with catchy melodies and the mixes themselves are great.\n\nWhen it comes to choosing either the Japanese or English dub
voteText: it simply all comes down to personal preference. The only gripe I have with the English dub is that it doesn't have voice acting during quite a few scenes where the Japanese one does. If you're the type of person who doesn't care about the language or expression
helpfulPercent: and would just like to have a full audio experience with speech
votesHelpful: then the Japanese option will give you that. Otherwise the English dub is still quite good. I myself am indecisive and keep switching between the two.\n\nThe visuals are of course much better in the PC version due to the improved framerate
votesTotal: and although the game doesn't have an in-built 1080p resolution option
votesFunny: there is a work-around posted in the forums.\n\nIf by any chance you are having issues with this game involving cutscenes being automatically skipped
commentsCount: you simply need to go and install CCCP or the "Combined Community Codec Pack". It'll fix a lot of issues you may have with other forms of media as well. Thankfully I've yet to come across a single bug in this game myself.\n\nIt's been said by a fair few people
column16: but it's true that a controller is optimal for playing this game. The in-game tutorials present you with buttons for a controller setup without giving you direct guidance for a mouse and keyboard
column17: and even when you work it all out it's pretty unpleasant in its default state. Don't let that turn you off from this game if you're interested though
column18: because you can just reassign everything obviously. Even still
column19: go grab that controller to make it easy.\n\nAll-in-all this is the best Hyperdimension Neptunia experience I've had yet in terms of visuals
column20: audio and performance. If you're a fan of the anime aesthetic
column21: light-hearted humour
column22: cool combat and JRPGs in general
column23: then you're going to have a blast with this game. I hope to see the support being given to the PC release cause more games like this one to come to PC."

reviewText:
This is coming from a guy who has only heard of these games in passing before now. I had no idea what to expect when I was thrown ino this world. Good thing I didn't get time to prepare! Right from the get-go, this little lady Neptune, I had seen around the internet captured my attension, and she didn't let go!

From what I read online after Neptune herself commented, They really changed the story with this remake!" They really did change the entirety of the thing and it's suggested even those who played the original get into this too.

Let's talk about what this game is. Hyperdimension Neptunia is a traditional JRPG that parodies every bit of gaming you can imagine. From locations
date: like Halo Mountain and the Hyyrule Snowfield
recommended: to the discs upgrades which allow you to 'create' games like CoD and other such that give you awesome stats
hoursPlayed: to the fact they've stolen some Tales Of Series Hi-ougi (Mystic Arts). This game is a wash with references to Gaming
voteText: even Visual Novels like Stein's Gate get a nod. For those of you raised on gaming
helpfulPercent: this is a tribute!\n\nThe Combat system is the games most polished and strongest point. It reminds me of a far better version of the old Quest 64 Battle system
votesHelpful: On your turn you move within a certain circle on the battlefield to approach or get away from enemies and then unleash your combo attacks to ether build upyour EXE gadge for specials
votesTotal: break attacks which lowers the enemies guard bar for extra damage if it's depleted
votesFunny: and simple power attacks for damage. The characters have their own set of combos.\n\nSpeaking of the characters
commentsCount: they're fantasic

column17: and Company self inserts
column18: alongside of oneliner joke characters like Maryo and David Snake.\n\nThere are several weaknesses in this title however. First of all

column20: the 'dungeon' areas are lazilly constructed and most are carbon copies

column22: OH ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• BRAND NEW PLACE
column23: but the level design is simply lazy. Of course all the enemies are recolors too
column24: but this is a JRPG
column25: par for the course.\n\nAnother problem is localizaton. It's bad

reviewText:
Worth playing.

It's definitely the king of trope jrpgs, but it's really fun. Like most jrpgs, however, you need to do a lot of grinding. Spoiler alert: you'll want to be level 80 before you face off the final boss. There is new game+ and you get to keep all levels/items/etc that you've found/bought within the game, so there's plenty of replayability after you beat the game. Besides, there's a few characters you need to unlock through two separate playthroughs if you're going for all the achievements.

Also, boobs. Very important.

reviewText:
It's gonna take a bit of patience to get through the parts where grinding is almost necessary, but other than that, this is probably one of my favorite games ever.

High frame-rate automatically makes me like it more on PC, but I can't really relate too much to the Vita version, because I didn't go to far into it.

References to past games makes it a nice experience for those who've been into the series for a while.

If you're still not sure about it, maybe get it on sale one day, or pay full price and help out IFI so we can get more ports to PC.


Oh, by the way, Vert's got a great figure.

reviewText: as much as i want to love this game. im gonna hafta give it some bad scores. even so i still recommend it. first off the controls must be memorized to realy get a feel for the game because all explanation of controls are still listed in their original platforms gamepad. while the game does have a menu you can look too for keyboard layout.. unless you find the buttons to acess the right menus it does little good. so for those who want to know: while on map and in dungeon the o" key opens the ingame inventory/system settings menu. the buttons used for different attacks in battle are "u" "i" "o" or "enter key" for the bottom attack option as default. and for using items in battle press "r" to acess secondary battle options and the "k" key to use items. for these annoying reasons only i give the controls a 4/10 score. ah the graphics: i loved the graphics in this game very nice. so far it has never frozen for me and remains clear even in the worse of situations. 10/10 for graphics!  gameplay and storyline: i realy like the storyline but find some lingo to be even beyond my knowledge so it makes me think they were trying to reach out to even the most esoteric references just to put a smile on your face. and for the gameplay it was going fine until the west wind valley(dungeon number 3 without dlc). when i reached west wind valley at lvl 8 or 9 the balance between you are your enemies stayed good but when you reach the end of the zone thinking ok im lvl 10 or so now lets try this boss fight. no.. its not just 1 boss fight. its 1 boss fight folowed by another boss fight. you will not win. I had to grind till i was lvl 17 to stand a decent chance. now dont get me wrong i dont mind grinding

DLC does not make the fighting and gameplay broken. i kinda wished it did (or atleast made it easier for me) so for a overall score of 6.5/10 for the game. not a bad way to waste time if youve got the "memory" for it..   haha"

reviewText: This game is a turn-based rpg with a twist. Like, a DISSIDIA: Final Fantasy-like twist. You move characters semi-freely in a controlled area in order to adapt and survive more creatively than just the simple status effects and buffs that most games of this genre are limited to. The music has a funky fresh feel for the most part, but it will fit the mood when the mood gets moody. Hype Nep-Nep is very story-driven and also linear, but you can take things at your own pace to stay on top of your game. The Re;Birth series is a remake and it knows, oh how it knows. The fourth wall is virtually non-existent and we are all reminded that Neptune knows what the gamers want. I recommend this for those who like rpg's that are class-based, not class-ruled, and fair warning... I hope you like the grind. Because the grind is real. It is oh so real. All hail the Child Whale and the 5,000+ exp. it provides during its plentiful harvest, and may its eternal blubber be with you forever.

reviewText:
After beat and complete this game (CPU Candidates, Ultimate Weapons, Gear, Processors and Outfits) I feel its fair to review this game right now. And I would give it a 8.5/10

For me the most important thing are the mechanics for grinding, leveling and battle system on any RPG. And as this was my first 3D turn based RPG, it was fair easy and quick to understand to truly enjoy the battles each time.

The difficulty is important too and even when this is the fastest RPG I beat in real time it requires a good grinding between bosses as those can be pretty tough; don¬¥t expect your nowadays easy RPGs were you can beat the story mode without even grind at all.

The music is attractive and keeps you entertained while playing to fit each battle, specially the boss's theme as it should be. But I still cant help myself and feel like one specific track was directly taken from a Phantasy Star's game but I cant land my finger on wich one or be 100% sure about it.

My only disappointments were:
-Enemy's skins: not too many enemy so the colors" change for map and difficulty.
-Maps: More than once
date: the dungeon's repeat the same maps don¬¥t brings you high hopes when you visit a new dungeon for the first time but you already know where to expect monsters and the though enemy.\n-Lack of interaction: there isn't just enough time or events to get to know all the characters in the game as good as I would like to
recommended: I guess is to expect since this is a portable remake but it feels a little unfair."

reviewText:
This game is essentially what you would get if a visual novel and an RPG had a child that became self-aware and proceeded to destroy the fourth wall. This game does not take itself seriously whatsoever. It is packed full of references to anime and video games, and half the fun is trying to pinpoint them all. The other half of the fun is the combat. It is surprisingly compelling, considering what game we're talking about. The attacks feel satisfying and the combat has some depth, but the difficulty does spike at times. Sometimes you can even walk straight into a game over without realizing it. On the plus side, I have to say this game has some creative enemy designs. You can fight anything from a walking eggplant with a nurse cap to a two-legged horse with wings to a tetris block from hell. In the end, this game is just as genius as it is stupid.

The port is also really bad, and does not at all explain the PC controls. It is by all means playable with a keyboard, but the controls are really awkward. I recommend you play this with a controller if you can.

Also, there is fan service. Lots of it.

reviewText:
As a owner of the PS3 originals this remake is far, far, FAR better than the original PS3 game. The combat system actually makes sense with the improved combo system. Items can now be used as and when without resorting to some percential system as seen in the original. The dungeon environments are reasier to navigate as is going from one nation to the next, the original had a really awkward mini dungeon which had to be traversed to travel between nations. This was really tedious.

The visuals look lush on the PC. Running at 1920x1080 makes everything just pop visually. The frame rate is outstanding. I have not run into one single bit of stutter, glitch or tearing with the visuals. Something that I would find repeatedly with the PS3 original.

The story has also had a tighten in this remake. While it is still heavily cutscene driven, it is nowhere near as bad as the original. There were sections that would be bogged down with massive exposition dumps, now they are streamlined and while still lengthy offer more enjoyment.

reviewText:
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1

Before you read this review I have to warn you that I am slightly biased towards JRPG‚Äôs and Anime games. Though for this review I am gonna try my hardest to look at it from a neutral perspective while noting things that are bias. Also I have to note that I have not played any other game in the serie, and I do not plan on playing any of the older games. But I am quite excited to play Re;Birth 2&3

(This is also my first ever review)

If you do not feel like reading my whole review then here is a summary in Pros and Cons

ProsAddicting
Funny Characters
Good Animations
Great DLC
A lot to do even after the storyConsShort Story
Confusing Stats
A lot of text
Dull if you do not like weird humour Story6/10 (Written from how I saw the story)

Intro:
The story is set in a virtual world called Gamindustri, this dimension is ruled by 4 CPU‚Äôs that each rule over one of the big land masses. Neptune/Purple Heart of Plantune, Norie/Black Heart of Lastation, Vert/Green Heart of Leanbox, Blanc/White Heart of Lowee. These 4 rulers have been locked in an eternal war called the console war. During one of the battles, 3 of the CPU‚Äôs heard a voice that told them to gang up on Neptune and basically kicks her out of Celistan (A dimension only accessed by the CPU‚Äôs and other goddesses). This is what ended up happening and Neptune lost all her memories in the process. After falling from the skies Neptune was found by a girl called Compa that ended up taking care of here.
Main Story:
The main story of the game follows Neptune and Compa and later on many more friends in their quest to restore peace to Gamindustri as an evil Goddess named Arfoire. Arfoire plans to steal the goddesses powers and become a god over Gamindustri.
Personal Thoughts:
The reason I vote the story quite low is for one reason and one reason alone. I wish there was more. The concept really went home with me and I really wish the game was long and therefore the story being longer. I thought this game was just gonna be wall of wall of wall of text over and over again. So I used the speed up option a lot. Later on I realised that the story was quite interesting and I decided to take my time reading it all and I really enjoyed it.Overall I really like the story,  I am also a person who usually plays games because they are awesome and do not care that much about the story, but as I said this story felt great to me.


Combat7/10

The combat in this game is quite standard to JRPG‚Äôs. The onyl unique thing I would say this game as interms of combat is that after you do a normal attack you get the option to use a ‚ÄúRush‚Äù,‚ÄúStrong‚Äù, or Break ability. Depending on which you use you can difference effects and outcomes. If you have played other JRPG‚Äôs then you will be able to jump straight in and understand most of it quite fast. Most new JRPG players should be able to understand the system quite fast as well. The animations for the attacks are all really awesome and beautiful, and really add that extra bit of awesome feeling when you unload your strongest attacks. One big complaint I have (reason it is not a 10/10) is that you get really confused while reading the stats of your characters. There is nowhere (at least that I found) were it explains what every stat means. This can be really annoying while you are leveling as having more in certain stats for some bosses can help.

DLC10/10

When I first found out that the game had DLC I thought it would just be another DLC driven game. Oh boy was I wrong. First of all there are 5 DLC‚Äôs you would have to buy to have them all, the total cost of these 5 are less 6‚Ç¨. So the DLC‚Äôs are cheap, but what do they add you might ask? They only add bonus content that is no way needed for completing and getting both the endings of the games. The DLC‚Äôs add things like, more characters to play, new dungeons, more items that you get from those dungeons. And the DLC‚Äôs each raise the max level with 300 meaning if you have all 3 your max level will be 999 instead of 99 as in the original game. If you ask me THIS is how DLC should be made, being cheap and not affecting the experience of the story.


To me this game is almost perfect with only a few elements like the stats and the story bringing the game down a bit, but you can not have everything now can you. I rate the game as a whole 9/10.

To end this review I am gonna answer some questions. And of course all these answers will be based on my personal opinion

Questions.
Is the game worth getting?
YES, this game is really worth getting.
Is the game worth the price?
To be fair, I think it should be a little bit cheaper then it is now. Maybe 20‚Ç¨ instead.
Would I recommend this game to a JRPG/Non-JRPG player?
JRPG: If you like JRPG‚Äôs you will most likely like this game, and if you like Anime as well (Like me) I can almost guarantee that you will LOVE this game.
Non-JRPG: I would not recommend this game to someone that is trying to get into JRPG‚Äôs but if the person has a little experience with them I would send the game their way.

reviewText:
If I were to look at this game purely from an objective stand point, I'd probably go as far to say that this is not a good game. In a lot of ways it's a fairly bad game. The areas are incredibly repetitive going from Forest area to Snow area to Factory area pretty much exclusively bar the last dungeon, and not only are these dungeons very repetitive, they are also incredibly short 90% of the time and very linear 100% of the time. They are not randomly generated meaning you get one short floor and this gets tiring very fast as this can be, at times, an absolute grind fest of a game, especially early on, not so much in the late game. The music is incredibly forgettable and doesn't stand out at all and the voice acting (in English) ranges from pretty decent (Sam Reigal and Cristina Vee) to pretty awful (Almost everyone else). The story is very generic with the entire story being 'Evil Witch wants world domination' and the characters are also fairly one note receiving only small amounts development throughout.

That being said, when I look back at the time I had with this game, I had a good time. The game has it's charm, it's certainly not a bad looking game, the art style and direction is very nice with the characters design being good between all the different characters. The combat system implemented is very fun and active, going for a slight twist on Turn Based Combat, allowing characters to freely roam the arena and positions playing a role in combat. It reminded me of Ni No Kuni's combat, which I also enjoyed. There is a variety of different moves that are unlocked throughout the game that are all very well animated and are fun to watch (Even if that fun is diminished somewhat the 100th time you've used them) and there are a ton of characters to unlock on use which all play quite differently. The regular moves that you do in battle are also quite customisable, as you are allotted a certain amount of points to allocate to Guard Break, Power or Rush moves, and you can customise the moves to suite your play style. As well as combat customisability, there are also a variety of different costumes to change the appearance of all the characters if you're into that kind of thing (and if you're they type of guy to play this game, chances are you are) as well as accessories which change appearance as well. The game can also be quite funny at times, depending on your sense of humour.

Would I recommend this game? That is entirely dependent on what kind of games you like. If you were put off by anything that I said in that first paragraph, this game probably isn't for you and if you're not really into self aware humour, then avoid it like the plague. While this game certainly isn't a masterpiece, I had my fun with it and I would recommend it any of the stuff in the second paragraph sounded appealing. I don't think I'd pay full price for it (I bought it at 50% off) but for the price I paid, I definitely think I got my money's worth.

Final Playtime: 34 hours 54 minutes.

reviewText:
Playable remake of the 1st Neptunia game.

Pros:
+ Playable
+ Amazing and fun combat system
+ Great/Lovable character design
+ Good VA (both English and Japanese)
+ Graphics are pretty great considering that it's a Vita port
+ Waifus.

Mixed:
~ Good dialog. Gets annoying after a while
~ Somehow difficult without the DLC. At least, the dlc is cheap.
~ Less content than previous instalments, but still more than enough for the price


Cons:
- Will not stop talking during the fight, mixed voices down
- Lazy dungeon design (variations of 6 types)
- More varied enemy design than previous instalments, although I don't think there is even a single new one.
- Grindfest, especially if aiming to complete the game

All in all, still had a blast.

reviewText:
A very interesting game. I found it to be a very fun and relaxing game even though it could get pretty tough. SAVE OFTEN! The game is light on plot, but it has a fun atomosphere and it's really about the characters - which there are a lot of. Maybe even too many to fully enjoy them all. The battle system is nice and straightforward but has some depth to it.

In the end, your familiarity with the (Japanese) game industry and moe anime tropes will affect your enjoyment a bit. If you're really not into those things, this game may not have enough other stuff to keep you entertained.

I think you will already know if you want this game, honestly. You know from looking at the cover art if this is for you probably.

If you like Nepping Nep Neps you will enjoy this.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A good JRPG on steam, the story is light hearted and not too deep but the quirky characters keep it interesting.
The combat system is fun and surprisingly deep but poorly balanced; characters are pretty balanced until post-game but rush + exe spamming basically dominates most enemies when you manage to craft a EXE Gauge disc (which is to say, about midgame).
The difficulty is incostant to say the least: the game starts pretty easily, gets harder through the middle game, is really easy near the end and then spikes again in the post-game (if you have the DLC).
A normal playthrough will take about 20-30h, but there is plenty of unlockables for completionists which will need at least 3 playthroughs and many many more hours to 100%.
I didn't find the game to be too much grindy during a normal playthrough (actually, probably a little less than the average JRPG), you will need to grind a bit for the post-game stuff but still less than the average JRPG (I went from level 75 to 999 in about 4hours).
Technically, the game is about average: the graphic is not jaw-dropping but the art is nice, the music is not really memorable but does its job.
My main complaint about it is the fact that many dungeons and enemies are recycled or palette-swapped; it's pretty standard in JRPGs but in Neptunia this feels way worse and makes most dungeons anonymous and bland.
I feel like Neptunia is a nice RPG  definitely not groundbreaking but a solid 7/10 IMHO, maybe a little more if you the fanservice does not bother you, you can overlook the recycled assets and are a JRPG/Japanese culture fan.

reviewText:
I will spare you from the storyline. If you have any interest in this game whatsoever, you either already have a general idea of what the game is about, or you can look it up in less than five seconds.

So, a turn based JRPG which draws inspiration from many other video games all while maintaining a steady stream of jokes directed at other works of arts should be a fairly chaotic experience, right? Well, it is. And honestly, this game isn't for anyone. If you don't have any interest in either anime or manga, you might as well turn back now, as you would probably cringe at everything the characters say and do.

That's not to say the game is bad though. While the story is slightly lackluster, it's mainly about the hilarious dialogue. If you don't like characters breaking the fourth wall, trolling around or poking fun at each other, the door is still there for you to leave through. For me, who is studying Japanese, this was both fun and educational at the same time.
The combat is where the game shines though, and it reminded me strongly of games such as Dragon Quest. With three characters on the field at the same, with three more as support, one of the more intriguing parts is where you can decide your own battle strategy. Do you want to go full offense? Go with a group of melee fighters. Do you want to play cautiously? Go with long range fighters. And if you want more support, there is always the option for that too. Whatever your playstyle is, with near 20 different playable characters, there is always one that will fit you.

And there will be at least one character you will like more than the others. Oh, and while I'm at it, play it in Japanese, some scenes aren't translated fully to English so you will be left with a couple of quiet scenes.
In the end, the interactions are hilarious, the combat is addicting, and if you are a collector there are a lot of things for you to find and craft. Don't see this as a hardcore game, come here if you're looking for some relaxing light and easy fun. I can't wait for Re;Birth2!
